This process allows you to tailor settings for your group or instance, ensuring alignment with your lab‚Äôs requirements. Let me know if you need help with specific configurations!
reference: 1. In the left menu , go to Utilities . 2. Click on Settings . 3. In the Select Group Settings drop-down, choose your division number .

user_input: How do you customize the Parents and Children sections in Object forms?
retrieved_contexts:
['# Customise Parents and Children Sections in Object Forms

1. **Section Name**. Enter an alternative name for the **Parents** or 
   **Children** section. If empty the default is used
   (Parents/Children).
2. **Disable the section** for the *Object* type. No parents/children
   can be added to this *Object* type.
3. **Disable addition of any object type**. This removes the **+**
   button next to the section name, which enables to add as parent any
   *Object* type. In this way only *Objects* of types pre-defined in
   the form can be added.
4. To define which *Object* types should always be shown in the form of
   a this *Object* type, click the **+** button.
5. Select if this is a **Parent** or **Child** from the **drop down**.
6. Enter a **Label**, which is what is shown in the *Object* form.
7. Select the *Object* type from the **drop down**.
8. Specify the **minimum** and **maximum** number of parents needed as
   input for this *Object* type. This can be left empty if parents are
   not mandatory for this type. If a minimum is specified, this makes
   the addition of those parents mandatory. As many parents as
   specified in the minimum field will have to be added in order to be
   able to save the form.
9. Specify A**nnotations** (e.g. Comments) for this parent *Object*
   type.
10. Click the + button on the section to add an annotation field.
11. Select the **Annotation** field from the list of available fields.
12. Specify if the **Annotation** is mandatory.', '## Parent-child relationships - [ ] [Customize Parents and Children sections in Object Forms](/en/How_to_guides/Customize_parents_and_children_sections) - [ ] [Add a hint in Parents and Children sections](/en/How_to_guides/Add_hint_parents_and_children_sections) ## Barcodes - [ ] [Enable Barcodes](/en/How_to_guides/Enable_barcodes)', '# Customise Parents and Children Sections in Object FormsThe **Parents** and **Children** sections are automatically created in
all *Object* forms. It is possible to customise or remove these
sections, from the **Settings**, under **Utilities**.

Let‚Äôs consider an example. The default *Experimental Step*, present in
all openBIS instances, looks like the picture below: in the **Parents**
section, **General Protocol** is predefined. If we want to add a General
Protocol to the form, we use the **Search** or **Paste** options next to
General Protocol. If we want to add another parent, for example a
**Sample**, we need to use the **Search Any** or **Paste Any** next to
Parents. See also [Add parents and children to Experimental
Steps.](../../general-users/lab-notebook.html#add-parents-and-children-to-experimental-steps)

![image info](../../../_images/exp-step-parents-children-default.png)', 'To assign [Parent and Children](/en/concepts#parent-child-relationship) to Objects of the type - Experimental Step, select relevant Object, click on the **Edit** tab. In the *Parent* and *Children* section, click **Search The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to the Parent and Children sections Step 3: Click Search Any Step 4: Select Object Type Step 5: Enter Code or Name of the Objects to connect Step 6: Review the entries and Save.', '# Customise Parents and Children Sections in Object Forms

Now let‚Äôs see how the **Parents** and **Children** sections of an
*Experimental Ste*p can be configured in the **Object Types Definition
Extension** in the **Settings.**

![image info](../../../_images/Screenshot-2020-02-26-at-13.22.59-1024x705.png)']
response:
To customize the **Parents** and **Children** sections in Object forms, follow these steps:  

1. **Access the Settings**: Navigate to **Settings > Utilities** in the openBIS interface. Here, you can configure the **Parents** and **Children** sections for Object types.  

2. **Rename or Disable Sections**:  
   - Change the name of the **Parents** or **Children** section (default names are "Parents" and "Children").  
   - Disable the section entirely if you don‚Äôt want parents/children to be added for a specific Object type.  

3. **Control Object Type Addition**:  
   - **Disable "Add Any Object Type"**: This removes the **+** button, restricting additions to predefined Object types.  
   - **Predefine Allowed Types**: Click **+** to specify which Object types can be added as parents or children. For example, you might add "General Protocol" or "Sample" as a parent.  

4. **Set Min/Max Requirements**:  
   - Define the **minimum** and **maximum** number of parents/children required for the Object type. If a minimum is set, those entries become mandatory.  

5. **Add Annotations**:  
   - Include optional comments or notes for specific parent Object types. Click **+** to add an annotation field, select the field from a list, and mark it as mandatory if needed.  

6. **Edit Existing Entries**:  
   - For specific Object types (e.g., *Experimental Step*), go to the **Edit** tab, navigate to the **Parents/Children** section, and use **Search Any** or **Paste Any** to add or modify parent/child relationships.  

These steps allow you to tailor the Parents and Children sections to fit your workflow, ensuring data integrity and usability. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example for a specific Object type!
reference: In the left main menu, under Utilities select Settings . The Select Group Settings drop-down menu will appear. Select your division number to open your group settings. Click on the Edit tab, navigate to the Object type definitions Extension section and select the Object Type you want to customize. To deselect sections for Parents or Children, select the Disable section checkbox, to disable the addition of any Object type as Parent or Child, select the disable addition of any object type) checkbox. To make adding Parents and Children more convenient to users, enter a name under Section name (e.g., Parents - Section name: Instruments for Experimental Step). Review the changes and Save.

user_input: How do you delete Projects, Collections, Objects, and Datasets?
retrieved_contexts:
['## Edit and Delete Projects, Experiments, Experimental Steps*Projects*, *Experiments* and *Experimental Steps* can be edited at any
time, by selecting the **Edit** icon from the toolbar of the relevant
page.

*Projects*, *Experiments* and *Experimental Steps* can be deleted using
the **Delete** option under **More** tab in the toolbar.

![image info](../../_images/edit-delete-forms.png)

*Experiments* and *Experimental Steps* are moved to the **trashcan**,
from where they need to be removed in order to be permanently deleted
from the database. *Projects* are directly deleted, they are not moved
to the trashcan first. *Projects* can be deleted only after deleting all
the *Experiments* they contain.', '## History of deletionsWhen *Experiments/Collections*, *Objects* and *Datasets* in openBIS are
permanently deleted, i.e. they are removed from the trashcan, the
information of these permanently deleted entries is stored in the
database and it is visible in the admin UI.

*Spaces* and *Projects* are directly permanently deleted, without going
to the trashcan. Their information is also shown in the table of history
of deletions in the admin UI.

The table of history of deletions is under the **Tools** section, as
shown below.

For each deleted entry, the table shows:', '## Deletion of archived Data Sets(Since version 20.10.3) Archived data sets can be deleted permanently.
But they are still in the container files. In order to remove them also
from the container files a
[MultiDataSetDeletionMaintenanceTask](#../system-documentation/configuration/maintenance-tasks.md#multidatasetdeletionmaintenancetask)
has to be configured.', '## Delete CollectionsTo delete an existing Collection:

1. Select **Edit Collection** under the **More..** dropdown menu

![image info](../../../_images/delete-collection-1.png)

2. Select **Delete** under the **More..** drop down menu

![image info](../../../_images/delete-collection-2.png)', '# Move Collections to a different ProjectIt is possible to move one *Collection* with it entire content
(*Objects* + *Datasets*) from one *Project* to another.

If *Objects* contain parent/child relationships these are preserved.

This operation requires *Space Power User* or *Admin* rights.

To move *Collections* in the Inventory:

1. Go to the *Collection* page you want to move
2. Click on **Edit Collection**

![image info](../../../_images/edit-collection-1024x345.png)

3. Select **Move** from the **More..** dropdown

![image info](../../../_images/move-collection-more-dropdown-1024x466.png)

4. Enter the code of the *Project* where you want to move your
*Collection*. If you start typing the code, openBIS will prompt you with
a list of available options and you can select the appropriate one from
there.

![image info](../../../_images/move-collection-1024x142.png)

5. Click **Accept**

Updated on April 26, 2023']
response:
To delete **Projects, Collections, Experiments, Experimental Steps, Objects, and Datasets** in openBIS, follow these specific procedures based on the system's behavior:

### **1. Projects**
- **Delete directly** using the **Delete** option in the toolbar.  
- **Note**: Projects **cannot be deleted** if they contain any **Experiments**. First, delete all Experiments in the Project before attempting to delete the Project itself.  
- Projects are **permanently deleted** without being moved to a trashcan. Their deletion history is stored in the admin UI.

---

### **2. Experiments & Experimental Steps**
- **Delete via the toolbar**: Select the **Delete** option under the **More** tab.  
- **Trashcan**: Deleted items (Experiments and Steps) are moved to the **trashcan**.  
- **Permanent deletion**: To permanently delete them, navigate to the trashcan and remove the items.  
- **History**: Deleted entries are logged in the admin UI's "History of deletions" table.

---

### **3. Collections**
- **Step 1**: Go to the **Collection** page and select **Edit Collection** from the **More...** dropdown.  
- **Step 2**: Choose **Delete** from the **More...** dropdown to permanently delete the Collection.  
- **Note**: Collections are directly deleted without a trashcan step. Ensure all contained Objects and Datasets are handled before deletion.

---

### **4. Objects & Datasets**
- **Deletion process**: Objects and Datasets follow the same workflow as **Experiments**.  
  - Use the **Delete** option in the toolbar to move them to the trashcan.  
  - Permanently delete them by removing them from the trashcan.  
- **Archived Data Sets**: If archived, they can be permanently deleted using the **MultiDataSetDeletionMaintenanceTask** (configured in system settings).  

---

### Key Notes:
- **Trashcan behavior**: Experiments, Steps, and Datasets go to the trashcan; Projects and Collections are deleted directly.  
- **Admin access**: For permanent deletion, admin rights are required to access the "History of deletions" table.  
- **Parent-child relationships**: Moving or deleting Collections preserves Object/DataSet relationships.  

Let me know if you need examples or step-by-step guidance!
reference: Users can delete Projects, Default Experiments, Experimental Steps and Datasets in their Lab Notebook - My Space . In the divisions private Inventory , users do not have sufficient rights (Space/Project User ) to delete contents and need to contact Data Store Steward(s) (DSSt(s)). The DSSt(s) manage the divisions private Inventory and assign roles to users that support Inventory management. To delete contents, navigate to the relevant folder, click on the More drop-down menu, and select Delete . In the Confirm Delete window, enter the Reason ( mandatory) for deletion. Click Accept to confirm. Deletion of Default Experiments, Experimental Steps and Datasets can be reverted. Deleting Projects, on the other hand is irreversible . >Note that deletions from the Trashcan are irreversible .{.is-info} ---

user_input: How do you delete storage information from an Object?
retrieved_contexts:
['To delete storage information from an Object, navigate to the relevant **Object**, click **Edit** and navigate to the *Storage* section in the Object form. Scroll to the right in the Storage table and click on the **-** icon to delete the storage. The deleted Storage will be moved to the trashcan. To delete it permanently, delete it from the [trashcan](/en/How_to_guides/Delete_ELN). --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to Storage sections Step 3: Click - icon', 'The Storage Widget is disabled by default. To track storage positions for a particular Object Type, the storage must be enabled by a group The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Settings Step 2: Select division number Step 3: Click on Edit tab Step 4: Scroll down to Object Type definitions Extension Step 5: Select an Object type Step 6: Enable Storage Step 7: Review the entries and Save.', '## Delete storage positions

### Remove one of multiple positions in the same box

1. **Edit** the sample for which you need to remove the storage
   position in the box
2. Navigate to the **Storage** section at the end of the page
3. Click on the **table row** (see picture below)
4. **Unselect** the position you want to remove (eg. A5 in the example below)
5. Click **Accept**
6. **Save** the sample

![image info](../../_images/delete-storage-positions.png)



### Delete multiple storage positionsTo delete multiple storage positions from multiple samples we can use
the **Object Browser**.

1. Go to the **Object Browser** under **Utilities** in the main menu
2. Select **Storage Position** from the **Object Type** dropdown

![image info](../../_images/Batch-update-storage-positions.png)

3. **Filter** the table to find the storage positions you want to
delete
(see [Tables](additional-functionalities.html#tables))', '## Delete storage positions

### Delete multiple storage positions

4. Select the positions you want to delete from the table and click the
**Delete** button (see picture below)

5. You will be asked to provide a reason for deletion

6. The deleted storage positions will be moved to the trashcan and
should be removed from there to be permanently deleted (see
[Trashcan)](additional-functionalities.html#trashcan)

![image info](../../_images/storage-positions-multiple-delete-from-table-1024x582.png)

Updated on May 2, 2023', '## Delete storage positions

### Delete single storage positionsTo delete a single storage position from a sample:

1. Edit the sample for which you want to deleted the storage position
2. Navigate to the **Storage** section at the end of the page
3. Use the ‚Äú**‚Äì**‚Äù button in the **Storage Position** table, as shown
   in the picture
4. Save the sample

![image info](../../_images/storage-position-single-delete-1024x634.png)

Please note that the storage position deleted in this way is moved to
the trashcan. To delete the position permanently, this has to be deleted
from the trashcan (see
[Trashcan](additional-functionalities.html#trashcan)).



### Remove one of multiple positions in the same boxIf one sample has been assigned to multiple positions in the same box
and you need to remove only one or some of them, you can follow these
steps:']
response:
To delete storage information from an Object, follow these steps based on whether you're removing a single storage position or multiple positions:

### **Deleting a Single Storage Position**  
1. **Edit** the Object (e.g., a sample or ELN entry) for which you want to remove the storage position.  
2. Navigate to the **Storage** section at the end of the page.  
3. Locate the storage position you want to delete in the **Storage Position table**.  
4. Click the **"‚Äì" icon** (minus button) next to the position.  
5. **Save** the Object.  
   - The deleted storage position will be moved to the **trashcan**. To permanently delete it, remove it from the trashcan (see "Trashcan" documentation).

---

### **Deleting Multiple Storage Positions**  
1. Go to the **Object Browser** under **Utilities** in the main menu.  
2. Select **Storage Position** from the **Object Type** dropdown.  
3. **Filter** the table to find the storage positions you want to delete.  
4. Select the positions and click the **"Delete" button**.  
5. Provide a reason for deletion and confirm.  
6. The deleted positions will be moved to the **trashcan**. Permanently remove them from the trashcan to complete deletion.  

Let me know if you need further clarification!
reference: To delete storage information from an Object, navigate to the relevant Object , click Edit and navigate to the Storage section in the Object form. Scroll to the right in the Storage table and click on the - icon to delete the storage. The deleted Storage will be moved to the trashcan. To delete it permanently, delete it from the trashcan.

user_input: How do you edit Projects, Collections, and Objects?
retrieved_contexts:
['To edit Projects, Default Experiments - Collections and Experimental Steps - Objects , navigate to the relevant folder, click on the **Edit** tab, enter the changes, review and **Save**. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Enter the changes Step 3: Review the entries and Save.', '# Move Collections to a different ProjectIt is possible to move one *Collection* with it entire content
(*Objects* + *Datasets*) from one *Project* to another.

If *Objects* contain parent/child relationships these are preserved.

This operation requires *Space Power User* or *Admin* rights.

To move *Collections* in the Inventory:

1. Go to the *Collection* page you want to move
2. Click on **Edit Collection**

![image info](../../../_images/edit-collection-1024x345.png)

3. Select **Move** from the **More..** dropdown

![image info](../../../_images/move-collection-more-dropdown-1024x466.png)

4. Enter the code of the *Project* where you want to move your
*Collection*. If you start typing the code, openBIS will prompt you with
a list of available options and you can select the appropriate one from
there.

![image info](../../../_images/move-collection-1024x142.png)

5. Click **Accept**

Updated on April 26, 2023', '## Customise Collection View

In this case a user would need to click on **More..**, and **Edit**
**Collection** in order to see the metadata and be able to edit the
*Collection*.

![image info](../../_images/collection-list-view-edit-collection.png)

Updated on April 25, 2023', '## Create Collections of Materials

### Create the Project folderTo create the *Project* folder:

1. Click on the **Materials** folder
2. Click the **+ New Project** button in the form.

![image info](../../../_images/create-project-materials-1024x286.png)

3. Provide a description, if wanted. This is not mandatory.
4. Enter the **Code**. This will be the name of the folder, in this case SAMPLES. Codes only take alphanumeric characters and no spaces.

![image info](../../../_images/new-project-form.png)



### Create the Collection folderTo register the *Collection* folder, inside the *Project* folder:

1. Click on the *Project* folder, in this case **Samples**.
2. Click the **+ New** button in the main form and choose **Collection** from the dropdown.

![image info](../../../_images/Inventory-collection-registration-201011.png)', '## Batch update entries in several Collections

### XLS Batch Update Objects

You can then download the template that will allow you to update
*Objects* of the selected types to single or multiple *Collections*. The
*Space, Project, Collection* need to be entered in the file. The
complete path for *Projects* and *Collections* need to be used. In
addition, identifiers for the *Objects* need to be provided: identifiers
are unique in openBIS, by providing them openBIS will know which
*Objects* have to be updated. Example file:
[SAMPLE-GENERAL-REGISTRATION-EXPERIMENTAL\_STEP-MASS\_MEASUREMENT-SAMPLE-template](../../_downloads/57c14c7b3462ab4548df7acf13a44f3d/SAMPLE-GENERAL-REGISTRATION-EXPERIMENTAL_STEP-MASS_MEASUREMENT-SAMPLE-template-1.xlsx)']
response:
To edit **Projects**, **Collections**, and **Objects** in openBIS, follow these steps based on their specific type:

### **Editing Projects**
1. Navigate to the **Materials** folder in the Inventory.
2. Click the **+ New Project** button to create a new project (for editing existing projects, this step may vary depending on the interface).
3. Enter the **Code** (this becomes the folder name) and optional description. Codes must be alphanumeric without spaces.

### **Editing Collections**
1. **To modify metadata or view details**:  
   - Go to the **Collection** page.  
   - Click **More.. > Edit Collection**.  
   - Update metadata or settings and click **Save**.  

2. **To move a Collection to a different Project**:  
   - Go to the **Collection** page.  
   - Click **More.. > Edit Collection**.  
   - Select **Move** from the dropdown.  
   - Enter the target **Project code** (openBIS will suggest options).  
   - Click **Accept** to complete the move.  

### **Editing Objects**
- **Direct editing via UI**: The context does not specify a standard "Edit" tab for Objects, but metadata can often be adjusted through the Object's details page.  
- **Batch updates**: Use the **XLS batch update tool** (available in the Inventory) to modify multiple Objects at once. This requires:  
  - Providing the full path to the **Project/Collection**.  
  - Including unique **Object identifiers** (these are globally unique in openBIS).  

For all edits, ensure you have the appropriate permissions (e.g., **Space Power User** or **Admin** for moving Collections). Let me know if you need examples or further clarification!
reference: To edit Projects, Default Experiments - Collections and Experimental Steps - Objects , navigate to the relevant folder, click on the Edit tab, enter the changes, review and Save .

user_input: What rights do users have in their 'My Space' ELN?
retrieved_contexts:
['Users have Admin rights in their ELN Space-My Space by default. This allows them to manage access rights at the level of Space and Project. Changes apply to underlying contents (Collections, Objects and Datasets); download Datasets and save searches.', 'Users can manage access in their ELN - My Space at the Space and Project levels (access will apply to underlying contents: Collections/Objects/Datasets). To grant access to a Project, navigate to relevant Project, click on the More tab and open the dropdown Menu, select Manage access to open the from. Select Role , enter the Username (B The process is as follows: Step 1: More dropdown menu Step 2: Manage access Step 3: Select ‚ÄúRole‚Äù Step 4: Enter BAM username Step 5: Grant access', '## Roles and Rights The corresponding rights to openBIS User roles are summarized in the table below. For additional information on roles and permissions, please refer to the official openBIS docs [here](https://openbis.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user-documentation/general-admin-users/admins-documentation/user-registration.html#openbis-roles). | Role | Rights | |----------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Instance Admin (Data Store Team) | - Full access to the complete openBIS Instance- *Space*/*Project* Admin rights- Create and edit Masterdata- Create and edit *Spaces*- Create/manage *Space* Admin role | | Group Admin (Division Head, DSSt) | - *Space*/*Project* Admin rights- Customise the group‚Äòs ELN Settings- Revert deletions | | Space/Project Admin | - *Space*/*Project* User rights - Assign and remove *Space*/*Project roles*-Create *Projects*-Delete *Project*s, *Collections*, *Objects*, *Datasets*- Save searches | | *Space*/*Project* User | - Observer rights- Create *Collections* and *Objects*- Edit *Projects*, *Collections* and *Objects* | | Observer | - Read-only access- Download *Datasets*', '## Assign home space to a userWhen a home space is assigned to a user, this becomes marked as **My
Space** for that user in the lab notebook, as shown below.

![image info](../../../_images/menu-my-space.png)

When users are registered via the ELN UI, a *Space* with their username
is created (see [User
Registration)](#)
and this is automatically set as home space for the user.

The same happens in multi-group instances where spaces are created for
each user in the lab notebook section.

An *instance admin* can change the home space of a user or assign one to
a user that does not have a home space assigned from the admin UI, as
shown below.

![image info](../../../_images/home-space-admin-ui-1024x359.png)

Please note that when a user is inactivated, the home space assigned to
that user is moved in the ELN UI to the folder **Others (disabled).** If
this is not desired, the space should be removed as home space from the
inactivated user. This can be done by an *instance admin*.', '## Default roles assigned in ELNWhen a user is registered via the ELN interface, a *Space* (folder) with
the name of the user is automatically created under the Lab Notebook
main menu. The user is also assigned some default roles:

1. *Space admin* of the *Space* created for him/her under the notebook.
2. *Space user of* the Inventory *Spaces* (MATERIALS, METHODS by
   default), the STOCK\_CATALOG and the STORAGE *Spaces*.
3. *Space Observer* of the STOCK\_ORDERS, ELN\_SETTINGS and
   PUBLICATIONS S*paces*.

Modification to default rights can be granted by an *Instance admin*
from the *admin UI*, as explained below.

Overview of roles:
[openBIS Roles](#openbis-roles)']
response:
In your **"My Space"** ELN, you have **Space Admin** rights by default. This means you can:  
- **Manage access rights** at the Space and Project levels (e.g., grant or revoke permissions for others).  
- **Create and edit Projects, Collections, Objects, and Datasets** within your Space.  
- **Delete Projects, Collections, Objects, and Datasets** (with appropriate permissions).  
- **Save searches** for datasets or objects for later retrieval.  
- **Download Datasets** stored in your Space.  

Additionally, you have **Space User** rights for Inventory Spaces like **MATERIALS**, **METHODS**, **STOCK_CATALOG**, and **STORAGE**, allowing you to:  
- **Create Collections and Objects** in these spaces.  
- **Edit Projects, Collections, and Objects** (within your permissions).  

As a Space Admin, you also control who can access your Space and its contents, ensuring you maintain full oversight of your work environment. Let me know if you'd like to adjust these settings or need help managing access!
reference: Users have Admin rights in their ELN Space-My Space by default. This allows them to manage access rights at the level of Space and Project. Changes apply to underlying contents (Collections, Objects and Datasets); download Datasets and save searches.

user_input: How do you embed images into descriptions or text fields?
retrieved_contexts:
['To embed an image (.jpeg, .png formats) in the description of the Entity during the editing, drag an image in the description field. The process is as follows: Step 1: Click Upload button Step 2: Select ELN Preview in the Dataset Type (*) Step 3: Select files to upload Step 4: Review the files and Save.', '## Rich Text Editor

### EMBED IMAGES IN TEXT FIELDSTo embed an image in the a text field with the Rich Text Editor (RTE) enabled, you can simply drag & drop a .png or .jpg file and resize the image by clicking on and dragging the corners.

![image info](../../_images/picture-inserted-in-RTE-1024x697.png)', '## Register a new Object Type1. Select **Types -> Object Types** from the menu.
2. Click **Add** at the bottom of the page.

![](../../../_images/add-object-type-1024x382.png)

![](../../../_images/add-new-object-type-1024x539.png)', '## Organising Definitions**Type definitions:**

The order of type definitions is not important for the Excel import
service, with exception of Vocabularies, those need to be placed before
the property types that use them.

**Entity definitions:**

Type definitions for the entities should already exist in the database
at the time when entities are registered. Generally Entity definitions
are placed at the end.



### Text cell formatting (colours, fonts, font style, text decorations)All types of formatting are permitted, and users are encouraged to use
them to make their excel files more readable. Adding any non text
element (table, clipart) will cause the import to fail.

![image info](../../_images/94.png)

(A valid, but not easily readable, example)', '## Registration of PropertiesWhen registering new properties, the fields below need to be filled in.

![](../../../_images/new-property.png)

1. **Code.** Unique identifier of the property. Codes can only contain
   A-Z, a-z, 0-9 and \_, -, .
2. **Data Type.** See below for data types definitions.
3. **Label.** This is the property/column header that the user can see
   in the ELN.
4. **Description**: The description is shown inside a field, to give
   hints about the field itself. In most cases, label and description
   can be the same.
5. **Dynamic Property Plugin**: Script for calculated properties.
   See [Dynamic properties](../properties-handled-by-scripts.html#dynamic-properties)
6. **Editable**: Editable in the ELN interface. In some cases, metadata
   is automatically imported by scripts and this should not be changed
   by users in the interface.
7. **Mandatory**: Field can be set as mandatory.']
response:
To embed images into descriptions or text fields in openBIS, you have two primary methods depending on the context:

1. **For Entity Descriptions (Non-RTE Fields):**  
   - Click the **Upload** button.  
   - Select **ELN Preview** as the Dataset Type.  
   - Upload your image file (supports .jpeg and .png formats).  
   - Review the uploaded files and click **Save** to embed the image into the description.

2. **For Text Fields Using the Rich Text Editor (RTE):**  
   - Open the text field with RTE enabled.  
   - Drag and drop your image file (supports .png and .jpg formats) directly into the editor.  
   - Resize the image by clicking and dragging the corners to adjust its dimensions.  

Both methods allow you to seamlessly integrate images into your data entries, enhancing clarity and visual context. Let me know if you need help with specific use cases!
reference: To embed an image (.jpeg, .png formats) in the description of the Entity during the editing, drag an image in the description field. Another way is to click on the picture icon ( ) in the rich text editor field. Alternatively, the image (.jpeg, .png, .pdf, .svg formats) could be embedded as an ELN Preview Dataset . For that, select relevant Default Experiment (Collections) or Object , and upload the Dataset. In the Create Dataset form, in the Data Set Type ( ) drop-down menu select ELN Preview . Fill out the relevant information and click on select files to upload, review the files and Save .

user_input: What is the purpose of enabling barcode/QR code functionality?
retrieved_contexts:
['## \U0001faaa Step 1: Choose the Code Content When an Object is registered, a Default Barcode is automatically generated by openBIS. This is found in Identification Info. It is also possible to use the PermId to generate a Barcode/QR code. ### Option A: **PermId** - **Pros**: - Always available and unique - Compact (suitable for Micro-QR) - **Cons**: - Tied to one openBIS instance - Changes on export/import - Only available after object registration ### Option B: **$BARCODE Property** - **Pros**: - Can be pre-assigned and batch imported - Compatible across systems - **Cons**: - Uniqueness not enforced - Requires additional data management ---', '# Enable Barcodes and QR codesIn order to be able to add custom barcodes and QR codes to *Objects*, an *Instance
Admin* needs to add the $BARCODE property to the object type for which
barcodes/QR codes are needed.

The barcode functionality is disabled by default in the ELN UI. This can
be enabled by a *lab manager* or a *group admin* with admin right to
edit the **Settings**, as shown below.

![image info](../../../_images/Screenshot-2020-02-26-at-13.01.57-1024x705.png)

After enabling the option, please refresh your browser. The **Barcodes/QR Codes Generator** will be shown in the main menu under **Utilities** and a
barcode icon will be added above the menu.

![image info](../../../_images/Generate-custom-barcodes-qrcodes.png)

![image info](../../../_images/barcode-scan-tablet.png)

Information on how to use the Barcode functionality in openBIS can be
found
here: [Barcodes](../../general-users/barcodes.html)

Updated on April 26, 2023', 'Select an Object and open its **More** drop-down menu, select B**arcode/QR Code Print**. In the Print Barcode/QR Code window, select the code type and size and click on the **Download** tab. The code will be saved on your computer as a PDF file that you can print. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Open More drop-down menu Step 2: Select Barcode/QR Code Print Step 3: Select the code type and size Step 4: Download the code Step 5: Print.', '## Barcodes and QR codesThe barcode functionality must be enabled in openBIS by a *lab manager*
or *group admin*: [Enable
Barcodes and QR codes](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/enable-barcodes.html).



### Barcodes for individual samplesWhen a sample is registered, a barcode is automatically generated by
openBIS. This is found in the **Identification info** section, as shown
below.

![](../../_images/Default-sample-barcode-1.png)

This barcode can be printed and the label can be added to the vial
containing the sample. The option to print the barcode is under the 
**More..** menu

![](../../_images/barcode-print-more-dropdown-slide.png)

If a sample already has its own barcode or QR code, it is possible to scan this with
a scanner or the camera of a mobile device and assign it to the sample.
This can be done after registration of a sample, with the **Custom
Barcode/QR Code Update** option under the **More..** drop down.', '## Barcodes and QR codes

### Barcodes for individual samples

![](../../_images/barcode-udate-more-dropdown-slide.png)

The custom barcode will appear in the *Identification Info*. If a custom
barcode/QR code is registered, the print function shown above will print the
custom barcode /QR code, instead of the default one.



### Generate batches of barcodes / QR codesIn some cases there is the need to generate several barcodes/QR codes that can be
later on assigned to samples registered in openBIS.

To generate new barcodes, go to the **Barcodes/QR codes Generator** in the main
menu under **Utilities**.

![](../../_images/Generate-custom-barcodes-qrcodes1.png)

Users can select:

1. The type of barcode to generate:

   1. *Code 128*
   2. *QR Code*
   3. *Micro QR code*
2. The number of barcodes to generate
3. The layout:

   1. *Split*: one barcode per page
   2. *Continuous*: several barcodes in one page
4. The width of the barcode
5. The length of the barcode']
response:
Enabling barcode/QR code functionality in openBIS allows users to generate, assign, and manage custom barcodes or QR codes for objects like samples. This feature is essential for two key reasons:  

1. **Custom Barcodes/QR Codes**: After enabling, users can create unique barcodes/QR codes (e.g., for samples) that can be printed and physically attached to vials or labels. These custom codes can replace or complement the default barcode generated by openBIS, providing flexibility for lab workflows.  

2. **Batch Generation**: The functionality supports generating multiple barcodes/QR codes at once (e.g., for large batches of samples). This streamlines processes like labeling, tracking, and scanning, ensuring consistency and efficiency in data management.  

By enabling this feature, labs can seamlessly integrate barcode-based systems with openBIS, enhancing traceability and reducing manual errors in sample handling.
reference: To make barcodes and QR codes visible and usable for your group in openBIS.

user_input: How do you export (meta)data from the Lab Notebook and Inventory?
retrieved_contexts:
['## Export to File

### Export Lab Notebooks & Inventory Spaces

  + a **scripts** folder, which contains scripts associated with types in the metadata.xlsx file, if these are present;
  + a **data** folder which holds the content of spreadsheet fields and large text fields that exceed the size of an Excel cell;
  + a **miscellaneous** folder which contain images embedded in text of exported entries, if present.
* **Export data**. The default maximum size of all datasets to be exported is 10GB. This can be configured by a system admin in the [AS service.properties file](../../system-documentation/configuration/optional-application-server-configuration.html). We recommend to use [sftp](lab-notebook.html#data-access) to download large datasets.
  If **Make import compatible** is selected, datasets are exported in a **data** folder in a format ready to be uploaded in openBIS using the default eln-lims dropbox. If not, the datasets are exported in a **hiearchy** folder that matches the ELN hierarchy.
* **Include levels below from same space**. If selected, all hierachy levels below the selected entity and belonging to the same Space are exported.
* **Include Object and Dataset parents from same space**. If selected, Object parents and Dataset parents from the same Space are exported. Example: I export Object A, in Experiment A, in Space 1. Object B in Experiment B also in Space 1 is parent of Object A. When this option is selected, Object B is also exported, otherwise it is not.
* **Include Objects and Datasets parents and children from different spaces**. This allows to export Object and Dataset parents and children that belong to a different Space than the Space from where Objects and Datasets are being exported. Example: I export Object A in Space 1, which has parents in Space 2. If this option is selected, the parents in Space 2 are also exported, otherwise they are not.
* **Wait for download to complete in browser**. This is suitable when exporting only metadata or small datasets. When the dowload is ready, a zip file will be available to download from the browser.', '## Export to File

### Export Lab Notebooks & Inventory SpacesAll levels of the *Lab Notebook* and *Inventory* can be exported, using
the **Export** option in the **More..** drop down, as shown below.

**Space**

![image info](../../_images/new-export-space-2.png)

**Project**

![image info](../../_images/new-export-project-2.png)

**Experiment/Collection**

![image info](../../_images/new-export-experiment-2.png)

**Object**

![image info](../../_images/new-export-object-2.png)

**Dataset**

![image info](../../_images/new-export-dataset-2.png)

In each case, the following export options are available:

![image info](../../_images/new-export-options.png)', '## Export to File

### Export Lab Notebooks & Inventory Spaces

*Note: ensure that pop-ups are not disabled in your browser*.

* **Receive results by email**. If this option is selected, when the export is ready, you will receive an email notification with a download link. Email notification needs to be configured on *system level* during or after installation, as explained in [Configure Data Store
  Server](../../system-documentation/configuration/optional-datastore-server-configuration.html)

We provide below a couple of examples of the export, to clarify how it works.



### **1. Import-compatible export of a Space selecting all options**We select all options from the export widget, as shown below.

![image info](../../_images/space-export-all-options-import-compatible.png)

We export a Space called CATERINA in the Lab Notebook with all its sublevels (see below).

![image info](../../_images/export_example-lab-notebook.png)', '## Export to File

### Export Lab Notebooks & Inventory Spaces

* **Make import compatible**. If selected, datasets are exported in a **data** folder and are in a format ready to be uploaded in openBIS using the default eln-lims dropbox; the metadata are exported in a **xlsx** folder which contains information in a format ready to be uploaded via the openBIS admin UI.
* **Export metadata as PDF**. Metadata are exported in a **hierarchy** folder that keeps the folder structure of the ELN. At each level, one pdf file for each exported entity is generated.
* **Export metadata as XLSX**. Metadata are exported in one **xlsx** folder. The folder contains the metadata of all exported entities and the corresponding masterdata in a **metadata.xlsx** file. If **Make import compatible** is selected, this file is suitable for re-import in openBIS. If not, the file contains some fields which are not compatible with re-imports. These fields are: PermId of entities, registrator, registration date, modifier, modification date. In addition to the metadata.xlsx file, the **xlsx** folder might contain additional folders:', '## Export to ETH Research Collection

The data exported to the Research Collection is a .zip file that contains the metadata of the exported entries in 4 formats (.txt, .html, .doc, .json) and the data. The hiearchy (i.e.folder structure) used in the ELN is preserved in the exported .zip file.

A new entry with the details of this submission will be created in the
**Publications** folder in the **Inventory** after the submission
process in complete. This may take a few minutes.

The size limit for one single export to the ETH Research Collection is
10GB.']
response:
Exporting (meta)data from the Lab Notebook and Inventory in openBIS involves a few key steps and options to tailor the export to your needs. Here‚Äôs how it works:

1. **Access the Export Option**:  
   Navigate to the entity you want to export (e.g., a Space, Project, Experiment, Object, or Dataset). Click the **More..** dropdown menu and select **Export**. This opens the export configuration panel.

2. **Choose Export Settings**:  
   - **Import Compatibility**: If enabled, datasets are saved in a **data** folder (ready for re-import via the eln-lims dropbox), and metadata are exported in a **xlsx** folder (including a `metadata.xlsx` file for re-import). If disabled, datasets are saved in a **hierarchy** folder matching the ELN structure.  
   - **Export Metadata as PDF**: Generates a **hierarchy** folder with PDF files for each entity, preserving the ELN‚Äôs folder structure.  
   - **Export Metadata as XLSX**: Saves all metadata in a single **xlsx** folder, including a `metadata.xlsx` file. Note that fields like PermId or registration dates may not be import-compatible if this option is used alone.  
   - **Include Parents/Children**: Select options to include related entities (e.g., parents or children from the same space or different spaces).  
   - **Receive Results by Email**: Configure this system-wide to get a download link via email once the export is ready.  

3. **Export to File or Research Collection**:  
   - For standard exports, the result is a ZIP file containing folders like **scripts**, **data**, **miscellaneous**, or **hierarchy**, depending on your settings.  
   - For ETH Research Collection exports, the data is saved as a ZIP file with metadata in multiple formats (.txt, .html, .doc, .json) and the original hierarchy preserved. The size limit for this export is 10GB.  

4. **Download or Access**:  
   - For small datasets, download the ZIP file directly via the browser.  
   - For large datasets, use **SFTP** to download, as browser downloads may not handle very large files.  

Always ensure pop-ups are enabled in your browser, and check system configurations (e.g., email notifications or export size limits) for advanced settings! Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example of a specific export scenario.
reference: All (meta)data from the Lab Notebook and Inventory for which you have observer rights can be exported. Navigate to the relevant file, open the More drop-down menu, and select Export . The export window will open. Select the appropriate export options and Receive results by email instead of downloading in the browser to enable more efficient software performance. You will receive an email notification from datastore@bam.de with a download link.

user_input: How do you export data to Zenodo?
retrieved_contexts:
['To export data to Zenodo, you need a Zenodo account to generate a personal access token. To do this, log in to your Zenodo account, select **Settings**, ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Export Step 2: Select Export to Zenodo Step 3: Enter title of the submission Step 4: Click on Export Selected', '# Enable Transfer to Data Repositories

The **Export to Zenodo** functionality becomes available under the
**Utilities** menu (a refresh of the browser page may be necessary to
see the change):

![image info](../../../_images/export-to-zenodo-1024x862.png)

Updated on April 26, 2023', '## Export to Zenodo

### Export data to Zenodo

![image info](../../_images/export-to-zenodo-1024x8621.png)

The data exported to Zenodo is a .zip file that contains the metadata of the exported entries in 4 formats (.txt, .html, .doc, .json) and the data. The hiearchy (i.e.folder structure) used in the ELN is preserved in the exported .zip file.

After you hit the **Publish** button in Zenodo, a new entry with the
details of this submission will be created in the **Publications**
folder in the **Inventory**. Please note that this may take a few
minutes.

![image info](../../_images/publications-collection.png)', '## Export to Zenodo

### Create Zenodo Personal Access Token

![image info](../../_images/generate-zenodo-token-1024x498.png)



### Save Zenodo Personal Access Token in openBISAfter creating the personal access token in Zenodo, this needs to be
stored in openBIS, with the following procedure:

1. Go to **User Profile** under **Utilities** in the main menu.
2. Enable editing.
3. Add the personal access token from Zenodo.
4. **Save.**

![image info](../../_images/user-profile-session-token.png)



### Export data to ZenodoTo export data to Zenodo:

1. Go to **Exports** -> **Export to Zenodo** under **Utilities** in
   the main menu.
2. Select the data you want to export from the menu.
3. Enter a **Submission** **Title.**
4. Click **Export Selected** on top of the export form.
5. The selected data are transferred as a zip file to Zenodo. You are
   now redirected to Zenodo, where you should fill in additional
   metadata information.
6. Publish the entry in Zenodo.', '## Export to ZenodoopenBIS provides an integration with the **Zenodo** data
repository ([https://zenodo.org/).](https://zenodo.org/)

This enables data direct data transfer from openBIS to Zenodo. First of
all the connection to Zenodo needs to be configured on *system level*
in the DSS service.properties (see [How to configure the openBIS
DSS)](#../../system-documentation/standalone/optional-datastore-server-configuration.md)
If this is configured, a lab manager, who has admin rights for the
**Settings,** needs to enable it in the ELN, as explained in [Enable
Transfer to Data
Repositories](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/enable-transfer-to-data-repositories.html)**.**



### Create Zenodo Personal Access TokenIn order to be able to export data to Zenodo, you need a valid Zenodo
account. You also need to create a **personal access token.** This can
be done from the **Applications** under **Settings** in Zenodo, as shown
below:']
response:
To export data to Zenodo, follow these steps:  

1. **Create a Zenodo Personal Access Token**:  
   - Log in to your Zenodo account.  
   - Navigate to **Settings** > **Applications** and generate a personal access token.  

2. **Save the Token in openBIS**:  
   - Go to **Utilities** > **User Profile**.  
   - Enable editing and add the Zenodo token to your profile.  
   - Save the changes.  

3. **Export Data from openBIS**:  
   - Access **Utilities** > **Exports** > **Export to Zenodo**.  
   - Select the data you want to export.  
   - Enter a title for your Zenodo submission.  
   - Click **Export Selected** to initiate the transfer.  

4. **Complete the Zenodo Submission**:  
   - You‚Äôll be redirected to Zenodo, where you‚Äôll fill in additional metadata.  
   - Once ready, **publish** the entry.  

5. **Verify the Export**:  
   - A new entry will appear in the **Publications** folder under **Inventory** in openBIS.  
   - The exported data is archived as a `.zip` file, preserving the original folder structure and including metadata in formats like `.txt`, `.html`, `.doc`, and `.json`.  

Let me know if you need help with any specific step!
reference: To export data to Zenodo, you need a Zenodo account to generate a personal access token. To do this, log in to your Zenodo account, select Settings , Applications and copy the Zenodo token. Return to openBIS, select Utilities and then User Profile and copy the Zenodo API token .

user_input: How do you filter Objects within a Collection?
retrieved_contexts:
['## How to use the Data Store - main functions for Users ### How to start - [Log in to the BAM Data Store - main instance](How_to_log_in) - [Represent research data - Conceptual data model](Represent_research_data) - [Manage Access to Spaces and Projects](Manage_Access) ### Register data in the *Lab Notebook* - [Register a Project](Register_project) - [Register Collection of the type Default Experiment](Register_default_Experiment) - [Register non-sequential Experimental Steps](Register_non-seq_Experimental_Step) - [Register sequential Experimental Steps](Register_seq_Experimental_Step) - [Upload data](Upload_data) ### Connect Experimental Steps in the *Lab Notebook* - [Define Parents and Children of Experimental Steps](Parents_and_Children_Experimental_Steps) - [Display connections of Experimental Steps - Hierarchy Graph](Hierarchy_graph) - [Add multiple Children to an Experimental Steps - Children generator](Children_generator) ### Edit, Delete and Move functions - [Project Overview](Project_overview) - [Edit Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Edit_ELN) - [Delete Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Delete_ELN) - [Revert deletions of Collection, Objects and Datasets](Revert_deletions_ELN) - [Move Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Move_ELN) - [Move Experimental Step - Object with descendants](Move_with_descendants_ELN) - [History of Changes](History_ELN) ### Additional Function - [Embedding Images in Text Fields](Embedding_Images) - [Filter Objects within a Collection](Filter) - [Search - Global and Advanced search across all fields of all Entities](Global_advanced_search) - [Search for: Objects in the Inventory](Search_Inventory) - [Search for: Objects - Experimental Steps in the Lab Notebook and save search queries](Search_Experimental_Steps) - [Use saved search queries](Use_saved_search) - [Search for Datasets](Search_Dataset_Lab_Notebook) ### Additional Function - [Embedding Images in Text Fields](Embedding_Images) - [Filter Objects within a Collection](Filter) - [Search - Global and Advanced search across all fields of all Entities](Global_advanced_search) - [Search for: Objects in the Inventory](Search_Inventory) - [Search for: Objects - Experimental Steps in the Lab Notebook and save search queries](Search_Experimental_Steps) - [Use saved search queries](Use_saved_search) - [Search for Datasets](Search_Dataset_Lab_Notebook)', '## Register single entries in a CollectionIn this example, we will see how to register one *Object* of type
**Sample** in the **Raw Samples** *Collection.* The same procedure
should be followed to register any other *Object* in other
*Collections*.

1. Click on the **Raw Samples** *Collection* folder in the main menu.
2. Click the **New Sample** in the main page
3. Fill in the form
4. **Save**

Please note that the *Object type* shown in the **+New** button (in this
case **Sample**), is what is defined as *default object type* for the
*Collection*. If this is missing in the *Collection,* the button will
not be present.

![image info](../../_images/register-single-entry-collection-button-1024x299.png)

To register a different object type in the Collection:

1. Select **New Object** from the **More** drop down menu (as shown
   below)
2. Select the relevant *Object type* from the list *(Sample,* in this case).
3. Fill in the form
4. **Save**', '## Create Collections of Materials

### Create the Collection folder

3. Replace the automatically generated **Code** with something pertinent to the collection (e.g RAW\_SAMPLES)
4. Fill in the **Name** field (e.g. Raw Samples). Note that by default, the navigation menu on the left shows the name. If the name is not provided, the code is shown.
5. Select the **Default object type** from the list of available types. This is the *Object* for which the *Collection* is used. In this case, **Sample**.
6. Select the **Default collection view** (see **[Customise Collection View](../../general-users/inventory-of-materials-and-methods.html#customise-collection-view))**

![image info](../../../_images/new-collection-form.png)', '## Create Collections of Materials

### Add the ‚Äú+Object type‚Äù button in the Collection percentageIf you use a Collection for one Object type, you can display a button to add that type to the Collection, as shown below.

![image info](../../../_images/Collection-new-chemical-button.png)

For this you need to edit the Collection form and set the Default Object type, as shown below.

![image info](../../../_images/Edit-collection.png)

![image info](../../../_images/Collection-default-object-type.png)', '## Customise Collection ViewIt is possible customise the view of *Collections* in the ELN.

The default *Collection* can have a **Form View** or a **List View**.
Depending on this selection, the collection view will be different.

![image info](../../_images/customize-collection-view.png)

**Form View:** This shows the metadata of the *Collection* along with
the table of objects. This view is useful when a user wants to see
specific metadata for a *Collection*.

![image info](../../_images/collections-form-view-1024x575.png)

If you do not see the table with the Objects in the form, you need to
enable this by selecting **Show Objects** from the **More..** dropdown

![image info](../../_images/collection-form-view-show-objects.png)

**List View:** The metadata of the *Collection* is not shown in this
view, but only the table of objects is shown.

![image info](../../_images/collection-list-view-1024x408.png)']
response:
To filter objects within a Collection in the BAM Data Store or openBIS, you can use the **Filter Objects within a Collection** feature. This allows you to narrow down the list of objects based on specific criteria. Here‚Äôs how to approach it:

1. **Navigate to the Collection**: Open the specific Collection folder in the main menu (e.g., "Raw Samples").
2. **Use Filter Options**: While viewing the Collection, look for filtering tools. These might include:
   - **Search fields**: Use the search bar to enter keywords or specific metadata values (e.g., sample ID, date, or properties).
   - **Advanced filters**: If available, apply filters by selecting criteria such as object type, status, or other attributes.
3. **Leverage Saved Searches**: If you‚Äôve saved search queries previously, you can reuse them to quickly filter objects.

For detailed steps, refer to the **"Filter Objects within a Collection"** section in the [How to use the Data Store](How_to_guides.md) documentation. This covers how to refine your search within a Collection‚Äôs context. Let me know if you‚Äôd like help crafting a specific filter!
reference: Select relevant Collection , click on the FILTERS tab and select Filter Per Column . In the appeared line of the Properties fields enter a specific Property value(s) to narrow the filtering.

user_input: How do you perform a Global or Advanced Search across all entities?
response:
To perform a **Global Search** or **Advanced Search** across all entities in the BAM Data Store or openBIS, follow these steps:

### **Global Search**  
1. **Access the Global Search Window**: Locate the top-left corner of the main menu and click the **Global Search** window.  
2. **Enter Search Terms**: Input your search term(s) into the search bar. This search spans all database fields across all entities (e.g., experiments, samples, datasets).  
3. **Refine with Advanced Search**: Click the **Advanced Search** option to add filters, conditions, and operators (e.g., **AND** or **OR**) to narrow results.  
4. **Select Field Types**: Choose specific field types (e.g., text, numeric) to target your search.  
5. **Execute the Search**: Click the search icon to view results in a table format on the **Advanced Search** page.  

### **Advanced Search**  
1. **Use Filters and Conditions**: In the Advanced Search interface, define criteria by selecting fields, operators, and values. For example, filter by metadata attributes or property values.  
2. **Combine Search Terms**: Use logical operators (**AND**, **OR**) to combine multiple search terms.  
3. **Refine Global Search Results**: Advanced Search can further refine results from a Global Search, allowing deeper filtering (e.g., specific entity types or metadata ranges).  

Both methods are accessible from the main menu and are ideal for locating data across the BAM Data Store or openBIS systems. Let me know if you'd like an example of a search query!
reference: To search across all database fields, enter the search term in the Global Search window in the top left-hand corner of the main menu. The Advanced Search form opens and displays the first results. To continue an advanced search across all fields of all entities (Experiments/Collections, Objects, Datasets), select an option from Search For drop-down menu and the AND or OR operator, then click the Search icon. Narrow the search by selecting an option from the Field Type drop-down menu (the options displayed will vary depending on the search). Select Property from the Field Type drop-down menu and enter the values required by the system in Field Name , Comparator Operator and Field Value . To narrow down the search further, click on the + icon and enter values. Click on the Search icon to activate the search.

user_input: How do you display the hierarchy graph for Experimental Steps?
retrieved_contexts: ['To display Parent-Child connections in a hierarchy graph, navigate to one of the Experimental steps, click on the **More** drop-down menu, select **Hierarchy Graph**. The number of displayed Objects (Parents and Children) and **Types** can be adjusted for better visualization. In the hierarchy graph, the **eye** icon shows the Objects, the **arrow** shows the metadata, and the **plus** icon can be used to insert Parents and/or Children directly into the hierarchy graph. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on More drop-down menu Step 2: Select Hierarchy Graph and adjust the number of displayed Objects.', 'To generate a Project overview navigate to Project, open the More drop-down menu and click on Show Overview. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Open the More drop-down menu Step 2: Click on Show Overview.', '--- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click the + New tab Step 2: Select an Object Type - Experimental Step Step 3: Fill out the Experimental Step form Alternatively, select relevant Template Step 4: click on Templates tab, select Template and complete relevant information Step 5: Review the entries and Save.', '--- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to the Parent and Children sections Step 3: Click Search Any Step 4: Select Object Type - Experimental Step Step 5: Enter Code or Name of Experimental Step to connect Step 6: Review the entries and Save.', 'To register sequential Experimental Steps, register a new [Object](/en/concepts#object) at the Object level. To do this, select relevant Experimental Step - Object, click on the **+ New** tab, fill out relevant information, review and **Save**. >Note that the new Experimental Step is organized under a Children drop-down in the left-hand main menu.{.is-info} --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on + New tab Step 2: Select an Object Type - Experimental Step Step 3: Fill out the Experimental Step form Alternatively, select relevant Template Step 4: Click on Templates tab, select Template, modify Object name and complete relevant information Step 5: Review the entries and Save.']
response:
To display the hierarchy graph for Experimental Steps, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to an Experimental Step**: Open the specific Experimental Step you want to visualize.  
2. **Access the Hierarchy Graph**: Click the **More** drop-down menu, then select **Hierarchy Graph**.  
3. **Customize Visualization**: Adjust the number of displayed **Objects (Parents and Children)** and **Types** to optimize the view.  

In the graph itself, use the **eye** icon to show Objects, the **arrow** to view metadata, and the **plus** icon to add Parents or Children directly. Let me know if you'd like help connecting steps or adjusting settings further!
reference: To display Parent-Child connections in a hierarchy graph, navigate to one of the Experimental steps, click on the More drop-down menu, select Hierarchy Graph . The number of displayed Objects (Parents and Children) and Types can be adjusted for better visualization. In the hierarchy graph, the eye icon shows the Objects, the arrow shows the metadata, and the plus icon can be used to insert Parents and/or Children directly into the hierarchy graph.

user_input: How do you view the history of changes for entities?
retrieved_contexts:
['## Entity historyWhenever an entity of type *Collection/Experiment*, *Object* or
*Dataset* is modified in openBIS, the changes are stored in the
database. The stored changes are modifications to property fields,
addition and deletion of parents/children for *Objects* and *Datasets*,
changes of *Space/Project/Experiment/Object* ownership if an entity is
moved.

The **History** of changes of each entity is now available in the ELN
UI. In versions prior to openBIS 20.10.3 this was only available in the
core UI.



### History table for CollectionsIn a *Collection* page, the **History** can be accessed from the
**More..** dropdown list.

![image info](../../_images/history-collection-dropdown.png)

The **History** table shows the version number of the changes, the
author of the changes, the changes made (with the values before- in red,
and after the change ‚Äì in green), and the timestamp, i.e. the time when
the changes were made.', '## Entity history

### History table for Collections

For a *Collection*, the **PermID** (Permanent Identifier) of the
*Project* it belongs to is shown. If a *Collection* is moved from one
*Project* to another, the PermID of the old and new *Projects* are shown
in the history table.

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2022-02-28-at-22.57.24-1024x535.png)

The **show** option in **Full Document** shows the full metadata of the
entry (not only the changed fields) when changes were applied. This is
displayed in JSON format.

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2022-03-04-at-12.47.18-1024x506.png)



### History table for ObjectsFor every *Object*, the history of changes can be accessed from the
**More..** dropdown on the *Object* page.

![image info](../../_images/object-history-dropdown.png)', '## Entity history

### History table for Objects

For an *Object*, the **PermID** (Permanent Identifier) of the
*Collection* it belongs to is shown. If an *Object* is moved from one
*Collection* to another, the PermID of the old and new *Collections* are
shown in the history table.



### History table for DatasetsFor every dataset, the history of changes can be accessed from the
**More..** dropdown on the *Dataset* page.

![image info](../../_images/dataset-history-dropdown.png)

For a *Dataset*, the **PermID** (Permanent Identifier) of the
*Object*/*Collection* it belongs to is shown. If a *Dataset* is moved
from one *Object*/*Collection* to another, the PermID of the old and new
*Objects*/*Collections* are shown in the history table.', '## Deleted Entity HistoryLogging the history of deleted entities can be enabled / disabled in the AS service.properties using setting

```
entity-history.enabled = \[true | false\]
```

Since 20.10.1 the default value is true (meaning, entity history is enabled). Before 20.10.1 the default value was false.

Deleted entity history can be queried with script `$INSTALL_PATH/bin/show-history.sh`.', '## History of deletions

1. **Entity type**: this can be *Space*, *Project*, *Collection,
   Object, Dataset;*
2. **Entity identifier**: this is the PermID of the entity. *Spaces* do
   not have PermID, so the code of the *Space* is shown instead;
3. **Entity Space**: the *Space* to which the entity belonged;
4. **Entity Project**: the *Project* to which the entity belonged;
5. **Entity Registrator**: the user who registered the entity;
6. **Entity Registration Date**: the date of registration of the
   entity;
7. **Reason**: the reason of deletion of the entity;
8. **Description**: the PermID (*Collection*, *Object*), identifier
   (*Space*, *Project*),  dataset path (*Dataset*) of the entity;
9. **Content**: the metadata of the entity when it was deleted. This is
   available for *Projects*, *Collections*, *Objects*, *Datasets*, but
   not for *Spaces*;
10. **User**: the user who deleted the entity;
11. **Date**: the date and time of deletion of the entity.']
response:
To view the history of changes for entities in openBIS, follow these steps based on the entity type:

1. **Collections**:  
   - Access the **History** table via the **More..** dropdown on the Collection page.  
   - The table displays version numbers, authors, timestamps, and detailed changes (with pre-change values in red and post-change values in green).  
   - If the Collection is moved between Projects, the PermID of the old and new Projects is shown.  
   - For full metadata (not just changed fields), select the **Full Document** option, which displays the data in JSON format.

2. **Objects**:  
   - Use the **More..** dropdown on the Object page to access the **History** table.  
   - The table includes PermID of the Collection it belongs to, and if the Object is moved between Collections, the PermID of the old and new Collections is listed.

3. **Datasets**:  
   - Access the **History** table via the **More..** dropdown on the Dataset page.  
   - The table shows the PermID of the Object/Collection the Dataset belongs to. If the Dataset is moved, the PermID of the old and new Object/Collection is displayed.

4. **Deleted Entities**:  
   - Deleted entity history is enabled by default (since openBIS 20.10.1). To query it, use the script `$INSTALL_PATH/bin/show-history.sh`.  
   - This includes details like entity type, PermID, deletion reason, and metadata at the time of deletion (for Projects, Collections, Objects, and Datasets).

For all entity types, changes to ownership, parent/child relationships, and property modifications are tracked, ensuring transparency in data management.
reference: To access the history of Projects, Default Experiment - Collections, Experimental Steps - Objects or Datasets, navigate to the relevant folder, open the More drop-down menu, and select History . The History form shows previous values in red , updated values in green . >Note that Samples was the former openBIS term for Objects , and Experiment for Default Experiment - Collections.{.is-info}

To log in to the main BAM Data Store, follow these steps:
