user_input: How do you manage user access to Spaces and Projects?
retrieved_contexts:
['Users can manage access in their ELN - My Space at the Space and Project levels (access will apply to underlying contents: Collections/Objects/Datasets). To grant access to a Project, navigate to relevant Project, click on the More tab and open the dropdown Menu, select Manage access to open the from. Select Role , enter the Username (B The process is as follows: Step 1: More dropdown menu Step 2: Manage access Step 3: Select ‚ÄúRole‚Äù Step 4: Enter BAM username Step 5: Grant access', '## Share Lab Notebooks and ProjectsIt is possible to share either a complete lab notebook or single
*Projects*, using the **Manage Access** option in the **More..**
dropdown of a *Space* or *Project* page, as shown below.

![image info](../../_images/mangae-access-space-dropdown.png)

Available roles are:

1. **Observer**: read-only access to Space or Project
2. **User**: can create and modify entities in Space or Project
3. **Admin**: can create, modify and delete entities in Space or
   Project

The roles can be granted to:

1. **User**: the user needs to be already registered in openBIS. The
   username of the user needs to be entered.
2. **Group**: the name of a user group existing in openBIS needs to be
   entered.

![image info](../../_images/manage-access-labnotebook-space.png)

![image info](../../_images/manage-access-project.png)', '## openBIS roles

### Space/Project Power UserExtends *Space/Projec*t User permissions with some deleting, editing and
processing functionality. Permissions are limited to specified
*Space(s)* or *Project(s)*.

Can do everything that *Space/Project* User and additionally:

* create projects
* delete

+ projects
+ data sets
+ objects
+ collections

Please note that this role cannot be assigned via the ELN UI, only via
admin UI.



### Space/Project AdminExtends Space/Project Power User permissions allowing to manage roles
and projects inside given *Space(s)* or *Project(s)*.

Can do everything that Space/Project Power User and additionally:

* assign and remove Space/Project roles



### Instance AdminHas the full access to given openBIS instance.

Can do everything that Space/Project Admin and additionally:

* create', '## What UserManagementMaintenanceTask does

   1. `<group key>`: All users of the group will a member of this
      authorization group. This group has access rights to common
      spaces as specified.
   2. `<group key>_ADMIN`: All admin users of the group will be
      member of this authorization group. This group has
      SPACE\_ADMIN rights to all common spaces and all personal
      user spaces.
2. Creates common spaces if they do not exist and assign roles for
   these space to the authorization groups.
3. Creates for each user of the LDAP groups or the explicit list of
   user ids a personal user space with SPACE\_ADMIN access right
   (NOTE: since 20.10.1 creation of personal user spaces can be
   disabled by setting ‚ÄúcreateUserSpace‚Äù flag in the group
   configuration to false). The space code read  
   `<group key>_<user id>[_<sequence number>]` A sequence
   number will be used if there is already a space with code
   `<group key>_<user_id`>. There are two reason why this can
   happen:', '## Overview

Access to openBIS is controlled at the *Space* level, *Project* level or openBIS instance level (see [openBIS roles](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/user-registration.html#openbis-roles) ).']
response:
Managing user access to Spaces and Projects in openBIS is done through the **Manage Access** feature, which allows you to define roles and permissions for individuals or groups. Here‚Äôs how it works:  

1. **Grant Access via Manage Access**:  
   - Navigate to a Space or Project.  
   - Click the **More** dropdown menu and select **Manage Access**.  
   - Choose a role for the user or group:  
     - **Observer**: Read-only access (cannot edit or delete).  
     - **User**: Can create, modify, and delete entities (e.g., datasets, objects).  
     - **Admin**: Full control, including managing roles and permissions for the Space/Project.  

2. **Assign Roles to Users or Groups**:  
   - Enter a **username** (for individual users) or a **group name** (for existing user groups).  
   - Roles can also be assigned at the **Space/Project level** or **instance level** for broader access.  

3. **Administrative Roles for Advanced Control**:  
   - **Space/Project Power User**: Can create, edit, and delete entities within a Space/Project.  
   - **Space/Project Admin**: Manages roles and permissions for the Space/Project.  
   - **Instance Admin**: Full administrative access to the entire openBIS instance.  

4. **Group-Based Access Management**:  
   - For user groups (e.g., LDAP groups), you can create **common spaces** and assign roles to groups, ensuring consistent access across multiple users.  
   - Personal user spaces are automatically created for individual users with **SPACE_ADMIN** rights by default, unless disabled.  

This system ensures granular control over who can view, edit, or manage data within Spaces and Projects, tailored to the needs of your team or organization. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example of assigning roles!
reference: Users can manage access in their Lab Notebook - My Space at the Space and Project level (access applies to the underlying content: Collections, Objects, Datasets). To grant access to a Space or a Project, navigate to relevant folder, click on the More drop-down menu, select Manage access to open the form. Select Role and set grant to User or Group, enter the username (BAM username  lower case only) or division number (e.g. 1.0). Click Grant access to apply settings. To get an overview of who has access in your Lab Notebook, Space or Projects, navigate to the relevant folder, click on the More drop-down menu, select Manage access . In the Manage access to window, an overview (User, Group, Role) of the assigned access rights is displayed.

user_input: How do you move Projects, Collections, Objects, or Datasets?
retrieved_contexts:
['# Move Collections to a different ProjectIt is possible to move one *Collection* with it entire content
(*Objects* + *Datasets*) from one *Project* to another.

If *Objects* contain parent/child relationships these are preserved.

This operation requires *Space Power User* or *Admin* rights.

To move *Collections* in the Inventory:

1. Go to the *Collection* page you want to move
2. Click on **Edit Collection**

![image info](../../../_images/edit-collection-1024x345.png)

3. Select **Move** from the **More..** dropdown

![image info](../../../_images/move-collection-more-dropdown-1024x466.png)

4. Enter the code of the *Project* where you want to move your
*Collection*. If you start typing the code, openBIS will prompt you with
a list of available options and you can select the appropriate one from
there.

![image info](../../../_images/move-collection-1024x142.png)

5. Click **Accept**

Updated on April 26, 2023', 'To move content, navigate to the relevant folder, open the **More** drop-down menu, and select **Move**. Start typing the *Name* or *Code* of the folder you want to move the content to and select it from the available options. Click on ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Open More drop-down menu Step 2: Select Move Step 3: Enter Code or Name of the target Collection in the search field Step 4: Click Accept.', '## Move DatasetsIt is possible to move a *Dataset* from one *Experiment/Object* to
another *Experiment/Object*.

1. Click on the *Dataset* in the main menu
2. In the *Dataset* page select **Move** from the **More..** dropdown
3. Enter the name or code of the *Experiment* or *Object* where you
   want to move the *Dataset* to. If you start typing, openBIS will
   show you a list of possible entries that match what you entered.
4. Press the **Accept** button.

![image info](../../_images/move-dataset-more-dropdown.png)

![image info](../../_images/move-dataset-1-1024x241.png)', '## Move one Experiment to a different ProjectIt is possible to move one Experiment and all contained Objects and
Datasets from one Project to another.

If Objects contain parent/child relationships these are preserved.

To move one Experiment from one Project to another:

1. Select the Experiment you want to move from the main menu
2. Select **Move** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown

![image info](../../_images/move-experiments-to-other-project-1024x373.png)

3. Enter the code of the Project where you want to move your
Experiment. If you start typing the code, openBIS will prompt you with a
list of available options and you can select the appropriate one from
there.

![image info](../../_images/move-experiment-1024x168.png)

4. Click **Accept**

![image info](../../_images/move-experiment-accept-1024x120.png)', '## Move entries to a different CollectionYou can move entries to a different *Collection* either from the e*ntry*
form or from a *Collection* table.



### Move from entry formTo move entries to a different *Collection*, select **Move** from the
**More‚Ä¶** drop down menu in the entry form.

![image info](../../_images/move-menu.png)

You have the option to move to an existing *Collection* or to create a
new *Collection*.

![image info](../../_images/move-options.png)



### Move from Collection TableIt is also possible to move objects from *Collection* tables. You can
select one or multiple entries from a table and click on the **Move**
button.

Also in this case you can move to an existing *Collection* or create a
new one.

![image info](../../_images/move-from-table-1-1024x412.png)

Updated on July 27, 2022']
response:
To move **Projects, Collections, Objects, or Datasets** in openBIS, the process varies slightly depending on the entity type, but the core steps are consistent. Here‚Äôs how to do it:

---

### **1. Move Collections**  
- **To a Different Project**:  
  1. Go to the *Collection* page.  
  2. Click **Edit Collection**.  
  3. Select **Move** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown.  
  4. Type the **Project code** (or start typing to auto-suggest options).  
  5. Click **Accept**.  
  - *Note*: Parent/child relationships (e.g., Objects or Datasets) are preserved.  

- **To a Different Collection**:  
  - From the **entry form** or **Collection table**, select **Move** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown.  
  - Choose an existing Collection or create a new one.  

---

### **2. Move Datasets**  
- **Between Experiments/Objects**:  
  1. Click the *Dataset* in the main menu.  
  2. Select **Move** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown.  
  3. Type the **Experiment** or **Object** name/code (auto-suggestions appear).  
  4. Click **Accept**.  

---

### **3. Move Experiments**  
- **To a Different Project**:  
  1. Select the *Experiment* from the main menu.  
  2. Click **Move** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown.  
  3. Type the **Project code** (auto-suggestions appear).  
  4. Click **Accept**.  
  - *Note*: All contained Objects and Datasets are moved, and relationships are preserved.  

---

### **4. Move Objects**  
- **To a Different Collection**:  
  - From the **entry form** or **Collection table**, select **Move** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown.  
  - Choose an existing Collection or create a new one.  

---

### **Permissions & Notes**  
- **Admin or Space Power User** rights are required to move Collections, Experiments, or Projects.  
- Parent/child relationships (e.g., Objects within Collections, Datasets within Experiments) are preserved during moves.  

Let me know if you need a visual guide or example!
reference: To move content, navigate to the relevant folder, open the More drop-down menu, and select Move . Start typing the Name or Code of the folder you want to move the content to and select it from the available options. Click on Accept . To move an Object to a another Collection, navigate to relevant Collection and select the Collection List view. Select the Object to be moved and click on the Move tab that appears. In the Move Object window, select to move to an Existing Collection and enter the Code or Name of the Collection in which you want to move the Object. Otherwise, select New Collection, fill in the mandatory( ) fields, review them and click Accept .

user_input: How do you move an Object along with its descendants?
retrieved_contexts:
['The process is as follows: Step 1: Open More drop-down menu Step 2: Select Move Step 3: Select option (to move all descendants) Step 4: Enter Code or Name of the target Collection in the search field Step 5: Check the box Step 6: Click Accept.', 'To move content, navigate to the relevant folder, open the **More** drop-down menu, and select **Move**. Start typing the *Name* or *Code* of the folder you want to move the content to and select it from the available options. Click on ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Open More drop-down menu Step 2: Select Move Step 3: Enter Code or Name of the target Collection in the search field Step 4: Click Accept.', 'To assign [Parent and Children](/en/concepts#parent-child-relationship) to Objects of the type - Experimental Step, select relevant Object, click on the **Edit** tab. In the *Parent* and *Children* section, click **Search The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to the Parent and Children sections Step 3: Click Search Any Step 4: Select Object Type Step 5: Enter Code or Name of the Objects to connect Step 6: Review the entries and Save.', '## Move Experimental StepsTo move an *Experimental Step* to a different *Experiment*, choose
**Move** from the **More..** drop down, as shown in the picture above.

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2021-09-21-at-18.40.02.png)

It is possible to move *Experimental Steps* from the *Object* table
which is presented on an *Experiment* or *Collection* page.

Select the entries to move and use the **Move** button on the table. You
can move to an existing *Experiment*/*Collection* or create a new one.

![image info](../../_images/move-objects-from-object-table-in-collection-1024x527.png)', '## Move one Experiment to a different ProjectIt is possible to move one Experiment and all contained Objects and
Datasets from one Project to another.

If Objects contain parent/child relationships these are preserved.

To move one Experiment from one Project to another:

1. Select the Experiment you want to move from the main menu
2. Select **Move** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown

![image info](../../_images/move-experiments-to-other-project-1024x373.png)

3. Enter the code of the Project where you want to move your
Experiment. If you start typing the code, openBIS will prompt you with a
list of available options and you can select the appropriate one from
there.

![image info](../../_images/move-experiment-1024x168.png)

4. Click **Accept**

![image info](../../_images/move-experiment-accept-1024x120.png)']
response:
To move an **Object along with its descendants** in the BAM Data Store or openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Open the More drop-down menu** on the Object you want to move.  
2. **Select "Move"** from the menu.  
3. **Enter the Code or Name** of the target Collection (folder) where you want to move the Object.  
4. **Check the box** labeled *"Move all descendants"* (or similar wording, depending on the interface) to ensure all child Objects (descendants) are included in the move.  
5. **Click "Accept"** to confirm the action.  

This process ensures the Object and all its descendants are relocated together. If the Object has parent/child relationships (e.g., Experimental Steps or Samples), these connections are preserved during the move. For experiments or collections, the same "Move" option applies, with the target location specified via code or name. Let me know if you need an example!
reference: An Object can also be moved together with its descendant Objects (i.e. children, grandchildren, etc.) if all Objects (Parent and Children) belong to one and the same Collection of the Object to be moved. To do this, click on the Object in the Collection, the Object Form opens, open the More drop-down menu, and select Move . Select the option move the Object with all descendants and start typing the Name of the (existing) Collection to which you want to move the Objects, review, and click Accept .

user_input: How do you configure new storage facilities (fridges/freezers)?
retrieved_contexts:
['To configure Fridges and freezers, navigate to the left main menu, under **Utilities** select **Settings**. The Select Group Settings drop-down menu will appear, select your **division number** to open your group settings. Click on the **Edit** tab, and navigate to the *Storages* section, click on **+ New Storage** tab. Fill in the *New Storage* form. The Code in the *Identification Info* (if hidden, open the **More** drop-down menu and select *Show Identification Info*) and Name should be meaningful and descriptive to represent the storage location. The number of rows (shelves), columns (racks per shelf) and boxes allowed in a shelf must be specified. The validation level is the minimum information required about the storage (a. Rack validation. The position in the shelf and rack needs to be specified; b. Box validation. In addition to a., a box name needs to be specified; c. Box position validation. In addition to a. and b, the position in the box needs to be specified). Review the entries and **Save**. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Settings Step 2: Select division number Step 3: Click on Edit tab Step 4: Navigate to Storages section Step 5: Click on + New Storage tab Step 6: Fill out the New Storage form Step 7: Review the entries and Save.', '## Configure Lab StorageFridges and freezers can be configured in the **Settings**, under **Utilities**.

1. Go to **Settings**
2. Click **Edit**
3. Scroll down to the **Storages** section
4. Click the **+ New Storage** button above the storage table, as shown below.
5. Fill in the **Storage Form** as explained below

![image info](../../../_images/settings-new-lab-storage-1024x498.png)

**How to fill in Storage Form:**', 'The digital representation of laboratory storage must be configured by the Data Store Stewards (DSSt(s)) in your division. To add storage information to an **Object** during registration, navigate to the *Storage* section in the *Object* form. If the Object is already registered, navigate to the relevant Object, click **Edit** and scroll down to the *Storage* section. Click on the **+ New Storage Position** Tab. The *Physical Storage* form opens. Select **Storage** from the drop-down menu, specify the **position** of the Object (e.g., Rack, Box name to display Box position) mark the position of the Object within the Box, click on the ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to Storage sections Step 3: Click + New Storage Position Step 4: Specify Object Position (e.g., Rack, Box) Step 5: Mark the Object(s) position(s) within the Box Step 6: Click on Accept tab Step 7: Save Object form.', '## Configure Lab Storage

1. **Rack validation**. The position in the shelf and rack needs to be specified.
2. **Box validation**. In addition to **a**, a box name needs to be specified.
3. **Box position validation**. In addition to **a** and **b**, the position in the box needs to be specified.', '## Configure Lab Storage

1. **Code**. It is advisable to provide a meaningful code for the storage, rather than using the default, because this information is needed when registering storage positions in Batch mode. For example MINUS80\_ROOM\_A1
2. **Name**. The name is what is shown in most parts of the ELN. E.g. Minus 80¬∞C in Room A1
3. **Number of rows**. This is the number of shelves.
4. **Number of columns**. This is the number of racks per shelf.
5. **Allowed number of boxes in a rack**. This is the maximum number per rack. Enter a very high number if this is not important.
6. **Rack space warning**. Enter space as percentage. E.g. 80, means that the system will give a warning when 80% of a rack is occupied.
7. **Box space warning**. Enter space as percentage. E.g. 80, means that the system will give a warning when 80% of a box is occupied.
8. **Validation level**. This is the minimum level of information required about the storage:']
response:
To configure new storage facilities like fridges or freezers, follow these steps:

1. **Access Settings**: Navigate to the left main menu, under **Utilities**, select **Settings**.  
2. **Select Division**: From the **Select Group Settings** dropdown, choose your division number to open your group settings.  
3. **Edit Tab**: Click the **Edit** tab, then scroll to the **Storages** section.  
4. **Add New Storage**: Click **+ New Storage** to open the *New Storage* form.  

**Configure Storage Details**:  
- **Code**: Assign a meaningful code (e.g., `MINUS80_ROOM_A1`) for easy identification, especially for batch registration.  
- **Name**: Provide a descriptive name (e.g., "Minus 80¬∞C in Room A1") for display in the ELN.  
- **Rows/Columns**: Specify the number of shelves (rows) and racks per shelf (columns).  
- **Allowed Boxes per Rack**: Set the maximum number of boxes per rack (use a high number if not critical).  
- **Space Warnings**: Define occupancy thresholds (e.g., 80% for rack or box space) to trigger warnings.  
- **Validation Level**: Choose the minimum tracking requirements:  
  - **Rack**: Track shelf/rack position.  
  - **Box**: Track shelf/rack + box name.  
  - **Box Position**: Track shelf/rack + box name + position within the box.  

5. **Save**: Review the entries and click **Save** to finalize the configuration.  

This setup ensures proper inventory management and tracking for your lab storage! üß™
reference: To configure Fridges and freezers, navigate to the left main menu, under Utilities select Settings . The Select Group Settings drop-down menu will appear, select your division number to open your group settings. Click on the Edit tab, and navigate to the Storages section, click on + New Storage tab. Fill in the New Storage form. The Code in the Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info ) and Name should be meaningful and descriptive to represent the storage location. The number of rows (shelves), columns (racks per shelf) and boxes allowed in a shelf must be specified. The validation level is the minimum information required about the storage (a. Rack validation. The position in the shelf and rack needs to be specified; b. Box validation. In addition to a., a box name needs to be specified; c. Box position validation. In addition to a. and b, the position in the box needs to be specified). Review the entries and Save .

Please note that new *Object types* created in the admin UI, do not
automatically appear in ELN drop downs, but they have to be manually

2. Click **Add** at the bottom of the page.

![](../../../_images/add-object-type-1024x382.png)

![](../../../_images/add-new-object-type-1024x539.png)', '## Lab Notebook menuIt is also possible to customise which entities should be shown under
*Experiments/Collections* in the main menu under the **Lab Notebook**
section.

response:
To enable specific Object Types to appear in dropdown menus, follow these steps:  

1. **Access Settings**: Navigate to the **Settings** section in the main menu.  
2. **Select Your Division**: From the **Select Group Settings** dropdown, choose your division number to open your group settings.  
3. **Edit Tab**: Click the **Edit** tab and scroll down to the **Object Type definitions Extension** section.  
4. **Enable Dropdown Visibility**:

   - Check the **Show in drop-downs** option.  
   - You can enable multiple Object Types at once.  
5. **Save Changes**: Review your selections and click **Save** to apply the updates.  

This process ensures the selected Object Types are visible in dropdown menus across the system. If you‚Äôre creating a new Object Type, remember to manually enable it in dropdowns after registration. Let me know if you need help with specific Object Types!

Click on the Edit tab and scroll down to the Object type definitions Extension section, open the corresponding object type, and enable the Show in drop-downs option. You can edit several object types at the same time, review the changes and click on the Save.

user_input: How do you define Parents and Children for Experimental Steps?
retrieved_contexts:
['To assign [Parent and Children](/en/concepts#parent-child-relationship) to Objects of the type - Experimental Step, select relevant Object, click on the **Edit** tab. In the *Parent* and *Children* section, click **Search The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to the Parent and Children sections Step 3: Click Search Any Step 4: Select Object Type Step 5: Enter Code or Name of the Objects to connect Step 6: Review the entries and Save.', '## Add parents and children to Experimental StepsIn the default *Experimental Step* and in the *Entry*, there is a
**Parents** section where it is possible to specify links to materials
and methods from the *Inventory* or to any other *Object*, e.g. another
*Experimental Step* or *Entry*.

**Parents** are all samples/materials used in an experimental procedure,
standard protocols from the inventory followed in the experimental
procedure, the equipment used. It is also possible to set one
*Experimental Step/Entry* as parent of a second *Experimental
Step/Entry,* to keep the connection between the two.

The name of this section and which parents should be shown in the form,
is customisable by the *lab manager* or *group admin* as described in
[Customise Parents and Children Sections in Object
Forms](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/customise-parents-and-children-sections-in-object-forms.html)', '## Add parents and children to Experimental Steps

### Parent-child relationships between entries in lab notebook

![](../../_images/ELN-exp-step-from-exp-step.png)

If you do not wish to have this relationship established, you need to
create the new Object starting from the Experiment level, as shown
below.

![](../../_images/ELN-exp-step-from-experiment.png)', '## Examples of parent-child relationships1. One or more samples are derived from one main sample. This is the
   parent of the other samples:

![image info](../../_images/sample-vials.png)

2. One Experimental step is performed following a protocol stored in the
   inventory, on a sample stored in the inventory, using a given equipment. The protocol, the sample and the equipment are the parents of the Experimental step

![image info](../../_images/exp-step-parents.png)

3. One Experimental Step is done after another and we want to keep
   track of the links between the steps:

![image info](../../_images/exp-step-parents-children.png)', '## Parent-child relationships - [ ] [Customize Parents and Children sections in Object Forms](/en/How_to_guides/Customize_parents_and_children_sections) - [ ] [Add a hint in Parents and Children sections](/en/How_to_guides/Add_hint_parents_and_children_sections) ## Barcodes - [ ] [Enable Barcodes](/en/How_to_guides/Enable_barcodes)']
response:
In openBIS, **Parents and Children** for Experimental Steps are defined as relationships that link an Experimental Step to other objects (like materials, protocols, equipment, or other steps) that directly influence or are connected to its execution.  

### **What Are Parents and Children?**  
- **Parents** are objects (e.g., samples, protocols, equipment, or other Experimental Steps) that are used, referenced, or directly involved in the experimental procedure. For example:  
  - A sample used in the step (parent).  
  - A protocol from the inventory followed during the step (parent).  
  - A prior Experimental Step that this step depends on (parent).  
- **Children** are objects that depend on or are derived from the parent. For instance, a derived sample from a parent sample or a subsequent Experimental Step linked to a prior one.  

### **How to Define Them**  
1. **Edit the Experimental Step Object**:  
   - Open the Experimental Step in the openBIS interface.  
   - Navigate to the **Parents** and **Children** sections (customizable by lab managers).  
2. **Search and Link Objects**:  
   - Use the search tool to find relevant objects (e.g., materials, protocols, equipment, or other steps).  
   - Select the object type (e.g., "Sample," "Protocol") and enter its code or name.  
3. **Save Relationships**:  
   - Review the linked entries and save your changes to establish the parent-child connection.  

### **Key Notes**  
- **Customization**: Lab managers can tailor which objects appear in the Parents/Children sections.  
- **Examples**:  
  - A step using a specific sample as input (parent) and producing a derived sample (child).  
  - A step following a protocol (parent) and generating experimental data (child).  
  - Sequential steps where one step is a child of another (e.g., "Step B" is a child of "Step A").  

This system helps track dependencies, reproducibility, and workflows in experiments! Let me know if you need a step-by-step example.
reference: To assign Parent and Children to Objects of the type - Experimental Step, select relevant Object, click on the Edit tab. In the Parent and Children section, click Search Any and select the Type of the Object you want to add from the drop-down menu. Enter the Code or Name of the Object in the field and start typing to display available options for your group, select accordingly and Save . To define multiple Parents and Children at the same time, select the Paste Any option, add the Code or Name of respective Objects, review the entries, and Save . You can copy the Code/Name of Objects from another ELN page (Log in in the BAM Data Store in another browser window). Paste the Codes(s) or name(s) in the text fields, review and Save .

user_input: How do you define Parents and Children for Inventory Objects?
retrieved_contexts:
['To assign Parent and Children to Objects of a division‚Äôs private Inventory, select relevant **Object**, click on the **Edit** tab. In the *Parent* and *Children* section, click **Search The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to the Parent and Children sections Step 3: Click Search Any Step 4: Select Object Type - Instrument Step 5: Enter Code or Name of the Objects to connect Step 6: Review the entries and Save.', 'To assign [Parent and Children](/en/concepts#parent-child-relationship) to Objects of the type - Experimental Step, select relevant Object, click on the **Edit** tab. In the *Parent* and *Children* section, click **Search The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to the Parent and Children sections Step 3: Click Search Any Step 4: Select Object Type Step 5: Enter Code or Name of the Objects to connect Step 6: Review the entries and Save.', '## Parent-child relationships - [ ] [Customize Parents and Children sections in Object Forms](/en/How_to_guides/Customize_parents_and_children_sections) - [ ] [Add a hint in Parents and Children sections](/en/How_to_guides/Add_hint_parents_and_children_sections) ## Barcodes - [ ] [Enable Barcodes](/en/How_to_guides/Enable_barcodes)', '## Parent-Child Relationship A parent-child relationship is a directed link (or "directed edge" in graph theory) between two [*Objects*](/en/concepts#object) (Object1 --> Object2) or between two [*Datasets*](/en/concepts#dataset) (Dataset1 --> Dataset2) in an openBIS Instance. For a given relationship between two *Objects* (or *Datasets*), the *Object* with the outgoing edge is called the "parent" and the *Object* with the incoming edge is called the "child". It is not possible to have parent-child relationships between *Objects* and *Datasets* or between other entity types (e.g., [*Collection*](/en/concepts#collection)). Parent-child relationships can be used to represent different kinds of logical connections between *Objects* (or *Datasets*), e.g.: - a partition of an entity: *Object* "Sample 1" is parent of *Objects* "Sample 1A" and "Sample 1B" because the original sample was broken up into two smaller sub-samples, - context in a research process, e.g., Object "Experimental Step 1" is child of the Objects "Sample 1A" and "Measurement Device" because during the experimental step, the measurement device was used to measure some properties of the sub-sample,', '## openBIS parents and children---

*Objects* can be linked to other *Objects*, *Datasets* to other *Datasets* with
N:N relationship. In openBIS these connections are known as *parents*
and *children*.

![image info](../../_images/objects-parents-children.png)![image info](../../_images/dataset-parents-children.png)']
response:
To define **Parents and Children** for Inventory Objects in openBIS, you establish a directed relationship where one Object (the **Parent**) links to another (the **Child**). This relationship represents logical connections, such as hierarchical structures or contextual dependencies. For example, an Inventory Object like "Sample 1" could be a Parent of sub-samples like "Sample 1A" and "Sample 1B" if the original sample was split. 

**Steps to Assign Parents and Children to Inventory Objects:**  
1. **Select the Object**: Open the Inventory Object you want to edit.  
2. **Access the Edit Tab**: Navigate to the **Edit** tab of the Object.  
3. **Locate Parent/Children Section**: Go to the *Parent* and *Children* section.  
4. **Search for Objects**: Click **Search** and select the Object Type (e.g., Instrument, Experimental Step).  
5. **Enter Object Details**: Input the Code or Name of the Objects you want to link.  
6. **Review and Save**: Confirm the entries and save your changes.  

This process ensures the Parent-Child relationship is properly recorded in the system, enabling structured data management and traceability within openBIS.
reference: To assign Parent and Children to Objects of a divisions private Inventory, select relevant Object , click on the Edit tab. In the Parent and Children section, click Search Any and select the Type of the Object (e.g., Instrument of the public BAM inventory) you want to add from the drop-down menu. Enter the Code or Name of the Object in the field, start typing to display available options for your group. Select and Save .

user_input: How do you print a barcode or QR code for an Object?
retrieved_contexts:
['Select an Object and open its **More** drop-down menu, select B**arcode/QR Code Print**. In the Print Barcode/QR Code window, select the code type and size and click on the **Download** tab. The code will be saved on your computer as a PDF file that you can print. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Open More drop-down menu Step 2: Select Barcode/QR Code Print Step 3: Select the code type and size Step 4: Download the code Step 5: Print.', '## üì• Step 4: Print and Apply Stickers - Use durable stickers compatible with your printer - Include optional metadata (e.g., contact, organizational unit) - Apply to physical objects clearly and accessibly --- ### How to print Code from openBIS(tbL) - Print Barcode/QR code generated in openBIS ## üì° Step 5: Scan and Use in openBIS - Use barcode/QR readers (USB-HID or Bluetooth) - Scanned codes will: - Display object info - Link samples/devices in experiments > üß™ Example Use Case: Scan a sample‚Äôs QR code during an experiment to auto-link it to the experiment record in openBIS. ---', '## \U0001faaa Step 1: Choose the Code Content When an Object is registered, a Default Barcode is automatically generated by openBIS. This is found in Identification Info. It is also possible to use the PermId to generate a Barcode/QR code. ### Option A: **PermId** - **Pros**: - Always available and unique - Compact (suitable for Micro-QR) - **Cons**: - Tied to one openBIS instance - Changes on export/import - Only available after object registration ### Option B: **$BARCODE Property** - **Pros**: - Can be pre-assigned and batch imported - Compatible across systems - **Cons**: - Uniqueness not enforced - Requires additional data management ---', '## Barcodes and QR codes

### Barcodes for individual samples

![](../../_images/barcode-udate-more-dropdown-slide.png)

The custom barcode will appear in the *Identification Info*. If a custom
barcode/QR code is registered, the print function shown above will print the
custom barcode /QR code, instead of the default one.



### Generate batches of barcodes / QR codesIn some cases there is the need to generate several barcodes/QR codes that can be
later on assigned to samples registered in openBIS.

To generate new barcodes, go to the **Barcodes/QR codes Generator** in the main
menu under **Utilities**.

![](../../_images/Generate-custom-barcodes-qrcodes1.png)

Users can select:

1. The type of barcode to generate:

   1. *Code 128*
   2. *QR Code*
   3. *Micro QR code*
2. The number of barcodes to generate
3. The layout:

   1. *Split*: one barcode per page
   2. *Continuous*: several barcodes in one page
4. The width of the barcode
5. The length of the barcode', "## \U0001faaa Step 1: Understand Default Barcode Behavior - When an object is registered in openBIS, a **default barcode** is automatically generated. - This barcode is visible in the **Identification Info** section. - If it's not visible: - Click the **More** drop-down menu. - Select **Show Identification Info**. ---"]
response:
To print a barcode or QR code for an object in openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Select the Object**: Open the object‚Äôs record in openBIS.  
2. **Access the Barcode Option**:  
   - Click the **More** drop-down menu.  
   - Select **Barcode/QR Code Print**.  
3. **Configure the Code**:  
   - Choose the **code type** (e.g., QR Code, Code 128) and **size**.  
4. **Download the File**:  
   - Click the **Download** tab. The barcode/QR code will be saved as a **PDF file** on your computer.  
5. **Print**: Use a printer to print the PDF file.  

**Notes**:  
- The default barcode (automatically generated when the object is registered) is visible in the **Identification Info** section. If it‚Äôs not visible, use the **More > Show Identification Info** option to display it.  
- For custom barcodes (e.g., using PermId or pre-assigned $BARCODE properties), ensure the code is registered first.  
- If you need to generate multiple barcodes for batch printing, use the **Barcodes/QR codes Generator** tool under **Utilities** in openBIS.  

This process ensures the barcode/QR code is ready for physical application or scanning during experiments! üß™
reference: Select an Object and open its More drop-down menu, select B arcode/QR Code Print . In the Print Barcode/QR Code window, select the code type and size and click on the Download tab. The code will be saved on your computer as a PDF file that you can print.

['To generate a Project overview navigate to Project, open the More drop-down menu and click on Show Overview. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Open the More drop-down menu Step 2: Click on Show Overview.', 'To register a [Project](/en/concepts#project), navigate to the Lab Notebook in the left-hand menu, open the drop-down menu, select My Space and click on **+ New Project**. The Project form will open. Fill out the Identification Info (if hidden, open the **More** drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). Enter the Code and Description, review the entries and **Save**. Code* **Requirements**: - Mandatory for openBIS (*) - The process is as follows: Step 1: Select My Space Step 2: Click on + New Project Step 3: Enter Code and Description Step 4: Review the entries and Save.', 'To access the history of Projects, Default Experiment - Collections, Experimental Steps - Objects or Datasets, navigate to the relevant folder, open the **More** drop-down menu, and select **History**. The *History* form shows previous values in **red**, updated values in **green**. >Note that *Samples* was the former openBIS term for *Objects*, and *Experiment* for Default Experiment - Collections.{.is-info} --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Open More drop-down menu Step 2: History', '## Project OverviewIn the Project page you have the options to see:

1. Default Experiments and Experimental Steps with the field *Show in project overview = true*. This is a way to mark the most relevant Experiments and Experimental steps and see them at a glance on the project page (**Show Overview**).
2. All experiments belonging to the project (**Show Experiments/Collections**).

The two options are available from the *More..* dropdown on the Project
page.

![](../../_images/proejct-more-dropdown.png)

Below you see an example of an overview in a Project page.

![](../../_images/proejct-page-overview-1024x640.png)

Below you see an example of the visualisation of Experiments and
Collections in a Project page.

![](../../_images/project-page-experiments-view-1024x488.png)', 'To edit Projects, Default Experiments - Collections and Experimental Steps - Objects , navigate to the relevant folder, click on the **Edit** tab, enter the changes, review and **Save**. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Enter the changes Step 3: Review the entries and Save.']
response:
To generate a **Project Overview**, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Project page** in the Lab Notebook.  
2. **Open the "More" drop-down menu** located on the Project page.  
3. **Select "Show Overview"** from the menu.  

This action will display the Project Overview, which includes:  
- Default Experiments and Experimental Steps marked as relevant (*Show in project overview = true*).  
- All experiments and collections associated with the project.  

The Overview provides a visual summary of key data, making it easier to track relevant experiments and datasets at a glance. Let me know if you'd like further details!
reference: To generate a Project overview navigate to Project, open the More drop-down menu and click on Show Overview.

response:
To register a new **Collection** in the Inventory, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Inventory**: Access the Inventory section of the system.  
2. **Create a New Collection**:  
   - Click the **+ New** tab.  
   - From the **Experiment/Collection type** dropdown menu, select **Collection**.  
3. **Enter Key Details**:  
   - Provide a **Code** (a unique identifier for the Collection).  
   - Give the Collection a **Name** (this will be displayed to users).  
   - Specify the **Default Object Type** (e.g., Sample, Entry) and **Default Collection View** (e.g., List view).  
4. **Save**: Review the entries and click **Save** to finalize the registration.  

For advanced configurations, you may also define a **Description** and add a **validation plugin** (if metadata validation is required). This process ensures the Collection is properly structured for managing its associated Objects. Let me know if you need further details!
reference: To register a Collection in the Inventory, navigate to relevant Project, click on + New tab and select Collection from the Experiment/Collection type drop-down menu. The Collection form opens. Fill out the Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). Enter the Code , a meaningful Name , select Empty in Default object type and List view in Default collection view drop-down menu. >Note that Collections can contain Objects of one or many types. Arrange Objects in the Inventory in a meaningful way for the group. Objects can be moved together with descendants, only if they are in the same Collection (Move Objects to a different Collection). {.is-info}

registration of **Object** types. For Collection Types, you only need to
provide a Code (which is a unique identifier), Description and add a

4. Click **Save** on top of the form.

![image info](../../_images/labnotebbok-collection-form.png)', '## Register ExperimentsInside one *Project*, a user can register several *Experiments*, which can in turn be divided into single *Experimental Steps.*

openBIS provides by default 2 options for registering Experiments:

* **Default Experiment**: The form of the Default Experment contains several metedata fields that can be filled in by the user.
* **Collection**: This form has limited metadata fields. It should be considered as a folder, to be used in cases where a user only needs to group subsequent steps, and does not need any relevant information at this folder level.



### Register a Default Experiment:1. Navigate to the relevant *Project* in the **Lab Notebook** menu
2. Select **Default Experiment** from the **+New** dropdown, as shown below. *Please note* that your openBIS instance might have different types of Experiments, depending on how it has been configured by the Instance admin.

![image info](../../_images/ELN-default-experiment-registration-201011.png)']
response:
To register a **Collection of type Default Experiment**, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the relevant Project** in the Lab Notebook menu.  
2. Click the **+ New** tab and select **Default Experiment** from the *Experiment/Collection type* dropdown menu.  
3. Fill out the **Create Default Experiment form**, which includes metadata fields for details like the experiment‚Äôs description, associated samples, or other relevant information.  
4. Review the entries and click **Save** to finalize the registration.  

This process creates a **Collection** specifically categorized as a *Default Experiment*, which is designed to group experimental steps with structured metadata. If you need to organize steps without detailed metadata, a standard *Collection* (as described in other guides) might be more appropriate. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example form or further clarification!
reference: The Default Experiment is a type of Collection to group sequential or non-sequential Experimental Steps. To register an Experimental Step, navigate to the relevant Project , click on + New tab, select Default Experiment from the the window Select Experiment/Collection type. Fill out the Create Default Experiment form, review the entries and Save .

user_input: How do you register non-sequential Experimental Steps?
retrieved_contexts: ['Registration of Non-Sequential Experimental Steps To register non-sequential Experimental Steps, please proceed as follows: Step 1: Create a New Object At the Collection level (Default Experiment), create a new Object. Navigate to the relevant Default Experiment and select the + New tab. From the Select an Object Type drop-down menu, select Experimental Step. Step 2: Complete the Experimental Step Form Fill out the New Experimental Step form. To display the Identification Info, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info, if it is not already visible. To do this, select relevant Experimental Step - Object, click on the **+ New** tab, fill out relevant information, review and **Save**. >Note that the new Experimental Step is organized under a Children drop-down in the left-hand main menu.{.is-info} --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on + New tab Step 2: Select an Object Type - Experimental Step Step 3: Fill out the Experimental Step form Alternatively, select relevant Template Step 4: Click on Templates tab, select Template, modify Object name and complete relevant information Step 5: Review the entries and Save.', 'To register non-sequential Experimental steps, register a new [Object](/en/concepts#object) at the Collection level (Default Experiment). Navigate to relevant - Default Experiment, click the **+ New** tab, select **Experimental Step** in the Select an object type drop-down menu. Fill out the New Experimental Step form, display Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). The Code is automatically generated for Objects and can only be changed during registration. Give the Experimental Step a meaningful **Name**, as this will be displayed to the users, review the entries and **Save**. >Note that the new Experimental Step is organized at the same hierarchical level of Objects () in the Lab Notebook left-hand menu.{.is-info} To fill out the Experimental Step form with a [Template](/en/How_to_guides/Templates) predefined for the group by the Data Store Steward, click on the **Templates** tab in the New Experimental Step form, select **Template**, add information to the form as required, review the entries and **Save**. Reload the web page to see the changes.', 'Step 3: Use a Predefined Template (Optional) If a Template has been predefined by the Data Store Steward for your group, it may be used to populate the Experimental Step form. Click on the Templates tab within the New Experimental Step form, select the appropriate Template, complete any required information, review the entries, and save. Reload the web page to apply the changes. Process Overview The following diagram summarizes the registration process: graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: + New Step 2: Select an Object Type: Experimental Step Step 3: Fill out the Experimental Step form or use a predefined Template Step 4: Review all entries carefully and save', 'The Default Experiment is a type of [**Collection**](/en/concepts#collection) to group sequential or non-sequential Experimental Steps. To register an Experimental Step, navigate to the relevant **Project**, click on **+ New** tab, select Default Experiment from the the window Select Experiment/Collection type. Fill out the Create Default Experiment form, review the entries and **Save**. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on + New tab Step 2: Select Default Experiment Step 3: Fill out Create Default Experiment form Step 4: Review the entries and Save.']
response:
To register non-sequential Experimental Steps in openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Default Experiment**: Start by locating the relevant Default Experiment (a Collection used to group Experimental Steps). This is typically found under a Project in the Laboratory Notebook.  

2. **Create a New Experimental Step Object**:  
   - Click the **+ New** tab.  
   - From the **Select an Object Type** dropdown, choose **Experimental Step**.  

3. **Complete the Experimental Step Form**:  
   - The system automatically generates a **Code** for the step (this can only be modified during registration).  
   - Assign a **meaningful Name** to the step, as this will be displayed to users.  
   - If a predefined template exists (created by your Data Store Steward), click the **Templates** tab, select the appropriate template, and fill in any required details.  

4. **Save the Entry**:  
   - Review all information carefully.  
   - Click **Save** to finalize the registration.  

The new Experimental Step will appear at the same hierarchical level as other Objects in the left-hand menu of the Laboratory Notebook. If you need to adjust settings later, you can edit the step directly. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example!
reference: To register non-sequential Experimental steps, register a new Object at the Collection level (Default Experiment). Navigate to relevant - Default Experiment, click the + New tab, select Experimental Step in the Select an object type drop-down menu. Fill out the New Experimental Step form, display Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). The Code is automatically generated for Objects and can only be changed during registration. Give the Experimental Step a meaningful Name , as this will be displayed to the users, review the entries and Save .

response:
To register new **Objects** in the Inventory, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Relevant Collection**: Start by accessing the *Collection* where you want to register the Object (e.g., "Raw Samples").  
2. **Select Object Type**:  
   - If the default Object type (e.g., "Sample") is available, click the **New [Type]** button (e.g., **New Sample**) on the main page.  
   - If the default type is not available, click the **More** drop-down menu and select **New Object**. Then choose the desired *Object Type* from the list.  
3. **Fill Out the Form**:  
   - Provide a meaningful **Name** for the Object (this will be visible to users).  
   - The **Code** is automatically generated and can only be modified during registration.  
   - Complete the *Identification Info* (if hidden, use the **More** menu to expand it).  
4. **Save**: Review the entries and click **Save** to finalize the registration.  

For **batch registration** of multiple Objects across different Collections, use the **XLS/TSV Batch Register Objects** utility under the **Object Browser** (available in openBIS 20.10.3+). This allows you to register Objects of various types efficiently.  

Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example or need clarification on any step!
reference: To register Objects in the Inventory, navigate to the relevant Collection , click on the More drop-down menu, select New Object and Object Type from drop-down menu. Fill out the Object Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). The Code is generated automatically for Objects and can only be changed during registration. Give the Object a meaningful Name , as this will be displayed to the users, review the entries and Save .

Reload the web page to see the changes.', 'To register a [ The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on + New tab Step 2: Select Collection from the Experiment/Collection type drop-down menu Step 3: Enter Code and Name Step 4: Select in Default Object Type ‚Äì (empty) Step 5: Select in Default Collection view ‚Äì List view Step 6: Review the entries and Save.', '## Register ProjectsIn a personal folder, users can register one or more *Projects* they
currently work on. *Projects* in openBIS only have a **Description**
field, no additional fields can be added.

1. Navigate to the relevant *Space* in the *Lab Notebook* menu and click the **+ New Project**
   ![image info](../../_images/ELN-new-project.png)
2. Should you have an empty page, select **Show Identification Info** and **Show Description** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown
3. *Projects* do not have a **Name** field, but only **Code**. Codes can only take alphanumeric characters and no spaces. Codes are prettified in the Main Menu.
