response:
To register a new project in the Lab Notebook, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to Your Space**: In the Lab Notebook menu, select the relevant *Space* where you want to create the project.  
2. **Create a New Project**: Click the **+ New Project** button.  
3. **Fill in Identification Info**:  
   - If the *Identification Info* section is hidden, click **Show Identification Info** in the *More‚Ä¶* dropdown menu.  
   - Enter a **Code** (alphanumeric only, no spaces). This code will be displayed in the Main Menu.  
   - Add a **Description** to summarize the project‚Äôs purpose.  
4. **Save the Project**: Review your entries and click **Save** at the top of the form.  

Projects are organized under the selected Space in the Lab Notebook. They do not have a *Name* field‚Äîonly a *Code* and *Description*. Let me know if you need help with additional details!
reference: To register a Project, navigate to the Lab Notebook in the left-hand menu, open the drop-down menu, select My Space and click on + New Project . The Project form will open. Fill out the Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). Enter the Code and Description, review the entries and Save .

user_input: Who can register Projects in the private and public Inventory?
retrieved_contexts:
['New Projects can be registered by Data Store Stewards (DSSt(s)) with Group Admin [roles](/en/concepts#roles-and-rights) in division‚Äôs **private** Inventory *Spaces*. Projects in **public** Inventory *Projects* need to be registered by the Data Store team (Instance Admins), please contact at datastore@bam.de.', '## Register ProjectsIn a personal folder, users can register one or more *Projects* they
currently work on. *Projects* in openBIS only have a **Description**
field, no additional fields can be added.

1. Navigate to the relevant *Space* in the *Lab Notebook* menu and click the **+ New Project**
   ![image info](../../_images/ELN-new-project.png)
2. Should you have an empty page, select **Show Identification Info** and **Show Description** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown
3. *Projects* do not have a **Name** field, but only **Code**. Codes can only take alphanumeric characters and no spaces. Codes are prettified in the Main Menu.
4. Enter a **Description** for the project.
5. Click **Save** on top of the form.

![image info](../../_images/ELN-create-project.png)

In the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown you have additional options on what you can do
in the Project folder, as shown below.

![image info](../../_images/project-more-dropdown.png)', '## Registration of Properties

### Considerations on properties registration1. If you create a property with code ‚ÄúPROJECT‚Äù, you should not use the
   label ‚ÄúProject‚Äù. This will give an error if you use XLS Batch
   registration/update, because openBIS considers this to be an openBIS
   *Project*.
2. You should not assign more than 1 property with same label to the
   same *Object* type. If two or more properties with the same label
   are present in the same *Object* type, this will result in an error
   in the XLS Batch registration/update.



### Controlled VocabulariesControlled vocabularies are pre-defined lists of values for a given
field.

Existing Vocabularies can be visualised from the Types ->
Vocabularies Tab. Vocabularies staring with the ‚Äú**$**‚Äù symbol are
internal: they cannot be deleted and their terms cannot be deleted.
However, it is possible to add new terms to these vocabularies and these
can also be deleted.', '## InventoryThe inventory is usually conceived to be shared by all lab members. The
inventory is used to store all materials and protocols (i.e. standard
operating procedures) used in the lab. It is possible to create
additional inventories, for example of instruments and equipment.

The picture below shows an example of an Inventory with the different openBIS levels.

![image info](../../_images/inventory-data-model.png)', '## Batch register entries in several Collections

### XLS Batch Register Objects

You can then download the template that will allow you to register
*Objects* of the selected types to single or multiple *Collections*. The
*Space, Project, Collection* need to be entered in the file. The
complete path for *Projects* and *Collections* need to be used, as shown
in this example file:
[SAMPLE-GENERAL-REGISTRATION-EXPERIMENTAL\_STEP-MASS\_MEASUREMENT-SAMPLE-template](../../_downloads/0e3d3b2bad0c8b9bf27529bdf70c7889/SAMPLE-GENERAL-REGISTRATION-EXPERIMENTAL_STEP-MASS_MEASUREMENT-SAMPLE-template.xlsx)



### TSV Batch Register ObjectsThe batch registration via .tsv file allows to batch register only one
type of *Object* at a time. *Objects* however can be registered to
several *Collections*.

This batch upload method is kept for backward compatibility, but it will
be phased out.

![image info](../../_images/object-browse-batch-reister.png)']
response:
Projects in the **private Inventory** can be registered by **Data Store Stewards (DSSt(s))** who hold the **Group Admin** role within their division‚Äôs private Inventory *Spaces*.  

For **public Inventory Projects**, registration must be done by the **Data Store team** (specifically **Instance Admins**). If you need to register a project in the public Inventory, you should contact the Data Store team at **datastore@bam.de**.  

Let me know if you‚Äôd like guidance on the registration process itself!
reference: New Projects can be registered by Data Store Stewards (DSSt(s)) with Group Admin roles in divisions private Inventory Spaces . Projects in public Inventory Projects need to be registered by the Data Store team (Instance Admins), please contact at datastore@bam.de.

user_input: How do you register sequential Experimental Steps?
retrieved_contexts:
['Registration of Non-Sequential Experimental Steps To register non-sequential Experimental Steps, please proceed as follows: Step 1: Create a New Object At the Collection level (Default Experiment), create a new Object. Navigate to the relevant Default Experiment and select the + New tab. From the Select an Object Type drop-down menu, select Experimental Step. Step 2: Complete the Experimental Step Form Fill out the New Experimental Step form. To display the Identification Info, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info, if it is not already visible. The Code is automatically generated and can only be modified during the registration process. Assign a meaningful Name to the Experimental Step, as this name will be displayed to users. Please review all entries carefully before saving. ‚öóÔ∏è Note: The new Experimental Step will be organized at the same hierarchical level as other Objects in the left-hand menu of the Laboratory Notebook.', 'To register sequential Experimental Steps, register a new [Object](/en/concepts#object) at the Object level. To do this, select relevant Experimental Step - Object, click on the **+ New** tab, fill out relevant information, review and **Save**. >Note that the new Experimental Step is organized under a Children drop-down in the left-hand main menu.{.is-info} --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on + New tab Step 2: Select an Object Type - Experimental Step Step 3: Fill out the Experimental Step form Alternatively, select relevant Template Step 4: Click on Templates tab, select Template, modify Object name and complete relevant information Step 5: Review the entries and Save.', 'To register non-sequential Experimental steps, register a new [Object](/en/concepts#object) at the Collection level (Default Experiment). Navigate to relevant - Default Experiment, click the **+ New** tab, select **Experimental Step** in the Select an object type drop-down menu. Fill out the New Experimental Step form, display Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). The Code is automatically generated for Objects and can only be changed during registration. Give the Experimental Step a meaningful **Name**, as this will be displayed to the users, review the entries and **Save**. >Note that the new Experimental Step is organized at the same hierarchical level of Objects () in the Lab Notebook left-hand menu.{.is-info} To fill out the Experimental Step form with a [Template](/en/How_to_guides/Templates) predefined for the group by the Data Store Steward, click on the **Templates** tab in the New Experimental Step form, select **Template**, add information to the form as required, review the entries and **Save**. Reload the web page to see the changes.', 'Step 3: Use a Predefined Template (Optional) If a Template has been predefined by the Data Store Steward for your group, it may be used to populate the Experimental Step form. Click on the Templates tab within the New Experimental Step form, select the appropriate Template, complete any required information, review the entries, and save. Reload the web page to apply the changes. Process Overview The following diagram summarizes the registration process: graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: + New Step 2: Select an Object Type: Experimental Step Step 3: Fill out the Experimental Step form or use a predefined Template Step 4: Review all entries carefully and save', '## Register Experimental StepsAs mentioned above, the various steps executed when performing an
Experiment in the lab can be registered in openBIS as  *Experimental
Steps or Entries.*

The default *Experimental Step* has pre-defined fields, as shown below:

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2020-02-28-at-15.29.17.png)

An *Entry*, is a blank page, with no pre-defined fields:

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2020-02-28-at-15.29.33.png)

To register a default *Experimental Step* or *Entry*:

1. Navigate to the relevant **Experiment** in the *Lab Notebook* menu and click the **+ New** button, as shown below.
2. Select **Experimental Step** or **Entry**
3. Fill in the relevant information or select an available template from the list (see below).
4. If **Show in project overview** is set to true, this *Experimental Step* or *Entry* will be displayed on the *Project* page.
5. Click **Save** on top of the form.

![image info](../../_images/object-registration-201011.png)']
response:
To register **sequential Experimental Steps** in openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Experiment**: Go to the relevant *Experiment* in the Lab Notebook menu.  
2. **Create a New Object**: Click the **+ New** button.  
3. **Select Object Type**: Choose **Experimental Step** (or **Entry** if you prefer a blank page).  
4. **Use a Template (Optional)**: If a template is predefined by your Data Store Steward, click the **Templates** tab, select the appropriate template, and modify it as needed.  
5. **Fill Out the Form**: Complete the required fields in the Experimental Step form. The **Code** is auto-generated and can only be edited during registration. Assign a meaningful **Name** for clarity.  
6. **Review and Save**: Double-check all entries, then click **Save** at the top of the form.  

**Note**: The new Experimental Step will appear under the **Children** drop-down menu in the left-hand menu of the Lab Notebook. This hierarchical structure organizes sequential steps under their parent Experiment.  

Let me know if you'd like an example or need clarification on any step!
reference: To register sequential Experimental Steps, register a new Object at the Object level. To do this, select relevant Experimental Step - Object, click on the + New tab, fill out relevant information, review and Save . >Note that the new Experimental Step is organized under a Children drop-down in the left-hand main menu.{.is-info}

user_input: How do you allocate a storage position to a single Object?
retrieved_contexts:
['The Storage Widget is disabled by default. To track storage positions for a particular Object Type, the storage must be enabled by a group The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Settings Step 2: Select division number Step 3: Click on Edit tab Step 4: Scroll down to Object Type definitions Extension Step 5: Select an Object type Step 6: Enable Storage Step 7: Review the entries and Save.', 'To allocate storage position to multiple Objects, the Data Store Steward(s) for your group must customize the [*storage for Objects*](/en/How_to_guides#storage-for-objects) and [*Enable object types in drop-downs*](/en/How_to_guides/Object_types_in_drop-downs) so that *Allowed object types* are displayed in Excel spreadsheet for batch registration. To assign a storage location to multiple objects, navigate to the relevant **Collection** and select **XLS Batch Register Objects** from the **More** drop-down menu. Ensure that the required Object Types are displayed in the **Register Objects** window and click on **Download**. The Excel Template should contain at least two sheets (the SAMPLE and STORAGE_POSITION metadata). To link these sheets, the information in the $ column of the SAMPLE spreadsheet must match the *Parents* column in STORAGE_POSITION spreadsheet. Enter the numbers or letters proceeded by the $ symbol (i.e., $1, $2) in the $ column. Upload the updated file and click **Accept**. To find the *storage Code* required in the STORAGE_POSITION spreadsheet, navigate to **Utilities**, **Settings** (choose your division‚Äôs number), open the *Storages* section and select relevant storage to view its metadata. Enter the required information and save the file locally on your device. --- ```mermaid graph TB;', 'The digital representation of laboratory storage must be configured by the Data Store Stewards (DSSt(s)) in your division. To add storage information to an **Object** during registration, navigate to the *Storage* section in the *Object* form. If the Object is already registered, navigate to the relevant Object, click **Edit** and scroll down to the *Storage* section. Click on the **+ New Storage Position** Tab. The *Physical Storage* form opens. Select **Storage** from the drop-down menu, specify the **position** of the Object (e.g., Rack, Box name to display Box position) mark the position of the Object within the Box, click on the ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to Storage sections Step 3: Click + New Storage Position Step 4: Specify Object Position (e.g., Rack, Box) Step 5: Mark the Object(s) position(s) within the Box Step 6: Click on Accept tab Step 7: Save Object form.', '## Allocate storage positions to samples

### Register storage position for a single sample

2. In the widget that opens, select the appropriate **Storage** from the
   dropdown menu. Storage must be configured by a lab manager or group
   admin as explained in [Configure Lab
   Storages](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/customise-inventory-of-materials-and-samples.html#configure-lab-storage)

![image info](../../_images/storage-selection-1024x202.png)

3. Select the **position** in the storage (shelf and rack).

4. If the sample is in a box, provide a **Box Name.**

5. Select the **Box Size** form the list of configured sizes (the list
can be configured by an *Instance Admin)*.

6. Select the **Position** in the box.

7. Click **Accept.**

![image info](../../_images/storage-assign-positions-1024x355.png)

#### Add additional metadata to storage positions', '## Allocate storage positions to samplesIf we want to track the storage position of samples, openBIS provides a
graphical overview of lab storages.

Lab storages need to be configured by a *lab manager* or *group admin*,
as explained here: [Configure Lab
Storage](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/customise-inventory-of-materials-and-samples.html#configure-lab-storage)

This can be done in two ways:

1. add storage information on the sample form during (or after) sample
   registration
2. batch register storage positions for several samples



### Register storage position for a single sample1. Navigate to the **Storage** section, at the bottom of the sample
form. Click the **+ New Storage Positions** above the table, as shown
below:

![image info](../../_images/add-strorage-position.png)']
response:
To allocate a storage position to a single Object, follow these steps:  

1. **Ensure Storage is Enabled**: If the Object Type does not already have storage tracking enabled, first enable it via the **Settings** > **Division** > **Object Type Definitions** section. Select the Object Type, enable Storage, and save.  

2. **Navigate to the Object Form**: Open the Object‚Äôs form (either during registration or by editing an existing Object).  

3. **Access the Storage Section**: Scroll down to the **Storage** section. Click **+ New Storage Position** to add a new storage entry.  

4. **Select Storage and Position**:  
   - From the dropdown menu, choose the **Storage** (e.g., a rack or box).  
   - Specify the **position** (e.g., shelf, rack number).  
   - If the Object is in a box, provide the **Box Name** and select the **Box Size** from a predefined list.  
   - Mark the Object‚Äôs exact position within the box (e.g., slot or compartment).  

5. **Save the Information**: Click **Accept** to confirm the storage details, then save the Object form.  

This process ensures the Object‚Äôs physical location is recorded in the system, making it easier to track and manage storage efficiently. Let me know if you need help with batch registration or configuring storages!
reference: The digital representation of laboratory storage must be configured by the Data Store Stewards (DSSt(s)) in your division. To add storage information to an Object during registration, navigate to the Storage section in the Object form. If the Object is already registered, navigate to the relevant Object, click Edit and scroll down to the Storage section. Click on the + New Storage Position Tab. The Physical Storage form opens. Select Storage from the drop-down menu, specify the position of the Object (e.g., Rack, Box name to display Box position) mark the position of the Object within the Box, click on the Accept tab and then on the Save tab.

user_input: How should research data be conceptually modeled and represented?
retrieved_contexts: ['# Conceptual data Model To map research data in the Data Store ‚Äì openBIS Research Data Management system, data are stored together with all experimental steps, tangible and intangible objects (things you do, generate and have) that are relevant to generate traceable and reusable data. It is advisable that divisions create a conceptual data model to have a visual tool that supports the discussions and development of the data model. In BAM, the DSSt leads the design of the data model and coordinates the feedback rounds with the division members. An understandable data model for the division supports effective data management, analysis, and collaboration. It is recommended to understand the concepts from the beginning to improve and expand the data model according to the needs of the department. The following steps serve as a guide for creating a conceptual data model. Any visualization tool can be used, the [template](/files_concepts/guideline_represent_research_data_(2).drawio) in draw.io can be downloaded and reused to implement the following steps.', '## üóÇÔ∏è Represent research data in the Data Store - Create a Conceptual Model - [ ] Use the [Represent_research_data](/en/How_to_guides/Represent_research_data). Use the [template](/files_concepts/guideline_represent_research_data_(2).drawio) in (draw.io) to Identify key steps and data points in the workflow; map data in the folder structure for the Data Store and define parent-child relationships between objects. - [ ] Manage roles and rights at the Space and Project level to comply with agreements and contracts of related research projects.', '## 1. Draw the research data workflow - Identify the data (of any format, single or multiple files, datasets) to be stored in the Data Store. - Add the *things you do* (e.g., synthesis, measurements, analysis, etc.) to generate the data and specify them as Experimental Steps. Attach data to Experimental Steps. - Connect the Experimental Steps with unidirectional arrows to indicate the logically occurrence and dependency. - Add the things you generate, *tangible* or *intangible* (Samples, Materials, etc.). - Add the *things you have* or *need* to complete all Experimental Steps and that are relevant to generate traceable and reusable data. Use general categories such as Chemicals to simplify visualization rather than listing individual chemicals. - To simplify the flowchart, make sure all Experimental Steps have at least one dataset attached (otherwise, check whether the Experimental step is part of another). ![representrd_workflow_v03.png](/representrd_workflow_v03.png)', '## Map conceptual data model in the Data Store-openBIS data structure ### Register data in the Lab Notebook: - Register a Project - EuVSOP - Register a Collection ‚Äì Experimental Steps of the type Default Experimental Step - At the Collection level, register Objects of the Type -Experimental Step for EuVSOP- Synthesis, HEE Treatment. - At the Object level ‚Äì EuVSOP HEE Treatment, register new Objects of the Type ‚Äì Experimental Step for: Nanoparticle Iron quantification, Magnetic Characterization and Nanoparticle Size - Upload datasets to all Experimental Steps - Connect Experimental Steps: Edit EuVSOP Synthesis to define as Children the Experimental Step - EuVSOP HEE Treatment. ![4euvsop_eln.png](/use_case_pics/4euvsop_eln.png) ### Register items in the Inventory: - Use inventory spaces defined per default in division¬¥s inventory space (e.g., X.1 Equipment and X.1 Materials). - Register a Project-folder - Instruments in the folder (Space) X.1 Equipment - Register Instruments - Register a Project folder - Consumables in the folder (Space) X.1 Materials - Register a Collection ‚Äì Chemicals - Register Objects Chemicals with Batch update registration ![5euvsop_inventory.png](/use_case_pics/5euvsop_inventory.png) ![6euvsop_collection.png](/use_case_pics/6euvsop_collection.png)', 'Step 3: Use a Predefined Template (Optional) If a Template has been predefined by the Data Store Steward for your group, it may be used to populate the Experimental Step form. Click on the Templates tab within the New Experimental Step form, select the appropriate Template, complete any required information, review the entries, and save. Reload the web page to apply the changes. Process Overview The following diagram summarizes the registration process: graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: + New Step 2: Select an Object Type: Experimental Step Step 3: Fill out the Experimental Step form or use a predefined Template Step 4: Review all entries carefully and save']
response:
To conceptually model and represent research data effectively, follow these structured steps:  

1. **Define the Workflow**:  
   - Identify all data types (files, datasets) and experimental steps (e.g., synthesis, measurements, analysis) involved in your research.  
   - Map these steps in a logical sequence using unidirectional arrows to show dependencies. Attach datasets to experimental steps to trace their origin.  

2. **Visualize Relationships**:  
   - Use a tool like **Draw.io** (or any visualization tool) to create a diagram.  
   - Highlight **tangible** objects (e.g., samples, materials) and **intangible** objects (e.g., chemicals, equipment) with general categories (e.g., "Chemicals") to simplify the model.  
   - Define **parent-child relationships** between objects and steps to reflect how data is generated and connected.  

3. **Leverage Templates**:  
   - If a predefined template exists (e.g., for your group or project), use it to populate forms for experimental steps. This streamlines data entry and ensures consistency.  

4. **Organize Data Structure**:  
   - Structure data in folders within the Data Store, aligning with the workflow diagram. Ensure each experimental step has at least one dataset attached to maintain traceability.  

5. **Manage Roles and Access**:  
   - Configure roles and permissions at the **Space** and **Project** levels to align with research agreements or collaborations.  

6. **Register and Connect Data**:  
   - Register projects, collections, and objects (e.g., experimental steps, materials) in openBIS. Link related steps (e.g., "EuVSOP Synthesis" to "EuVSOP HEE Treatment") to reflect logical dependencies.  

7. **Document and Iterate**:  
   - Regularly review and refine the model with your team to adapt to evolving research needs. This ensures the model remains practical for data management, analysis, and collaboration.  

By following these steps, you create a clear, reusable framework that supports traceable, reproducible research while aligning with openBIS and the Data Store‚Äôs capabilities.
reference: To map research data in the Data Store  openBIS Research Data Management system, data are stored together with all experimental steps, tangible and intangible objects (things you do, generate and have) that are relevant to generate traceable and reusable data. It is advisable that divisions create a conceptual data model to have a visual tool that supports the discussions and development of the data model. In BAM, the DSSt leads the design of the data model and coordinates the feedback rounds with the division members. An understandable data model for the division supports effective data management, analysis, and collaboration. It is recommended to understand the concepts from the beginning to improve and expand the data model according to the needs of the department. The following steps serve as a guide for creating a conceptual data model. Any visualization tool can be used, the template.drawio) in draw.io can be downloaded and reused to implement the following steps.

user_input: How do you revert deletions from the Trashcan?
retrieved_contexts:
['To revert deletions, navigate to **Utilities** in the main menu and select the **Trashcan**. Open the **Operations** drop-down menu for the relevant content and click on **Revert Deletion**, a green confirmation message will appear. Reload the webpage and navigate to relevant folders to see the reverted deletions. >Note that deletions from the Trashcan are ***irreversible***.{.is-info} --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Trashcan Step 2: Open Operations drop-down menu Step 3: Click on Revert Deletion Step 4: Reload the webpage', '## Trashcan

If one entity was unintentionally deleted, the operation can be reverted
at this stage by choosing the **Revert Deletions** option from
the **Operations** drop down in the table.

![image info](../../_images/trashcan-1024x302.png)', 'To delete storage information from an Object, navigate to the relevant **Object**, click **Edit** and navigate to the *Storage* section in the Object form. Scroll to the right in the Storage table and click on the **-** icon to delete the storage. The deleted Storage will be moved to the trashcan. To delete it permanently, delete it from the [trashcan](/en/How_to_guides/Delete_ELN). --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Click on Edit tab Step 2: Navigate to Storage sections Step 3: Click - icon', '## TrashcanWhen *Experiments*, *Objects* and *Datasets* are deleted, they are moved
to the openBIS **trashcan**, under the **Utilities** main menu. Items
can be removed from the trashcan only by someone with *Space admin* or
*Instance admin* role. Deletion from the trashcan is **IRREVERSIBLE**.

Note: *Spaces* and *Projects* are directly permanently deleted, they are
not moved to the trashcan first.

To empty the whole trashcan, click the blue **Empty Trash** button above the table.

To delete permanently single entries choose one of two options from the
Operations dropdown:

* **delete permanently**: deletes permanently only the selected entry.
* **delete permanently (including dependent deletions)**: if the
  selected entry had children which are also in the trashcan, this
  option allows to permanently delete both the entry and its children.', '## Delete storage positions

### Delete multiple storage positions

4. Select the positions you want to delete from the table and click the
**Delete** button (see picture below)

5. You will be asked to provide a reason for deletion

6. The deleted storage positions will be moved to the trashcan and
should be removed from there to be permanently deleted (see
[Trashcan)](additional-functionalities.html#trashcan)

![image info](../../_images/storage-positions-multiple-delete-from-table-1024x582.png)

Updated on May 2, 2023']
response:
To revert deletions from the Trashcan, follow these steps:  

1. **Access the Trashcan**: Navigate to the **Utilities** menu in the main toolbar and select **Trashcan**.  
2. **Locate the Deletion**: Identify the item you wish to revert in the Trashcan table.  
3. **Revert the Deletion**:  
   - Click the **Operations** dropdown menu (usually located above the table).  
   - Select **Revert Deletion** from the options. A green confirmation message will appear.  
4. **Reload the Page**: Refresh the webpage to view the reverted changes.  

**Important Note**: Once an item is moved to the Trashcan, deletions from here are **irreversible**. Always verify the action before proceeding. Let me know if you need further clarification!
reference: To revert deletions, navigate to Utilities in the main menu and select the Trashcan . Open the Operations drop-down menu for the relevant content and click on Revert Deletion , a green confirmation message will appear. Reload the webpage and navigate to relevant folders to see the reverted deletions. >Note that deletions from the Trashcan are irreversible .{.is-info}

user_input: How do you scan barcodes or QR codes in openBIS?
retrieved_contexts:
['In the top **Main menu** next to the **Global Search** field, click on the **Barcode** icon. Use a **barcode scanner** or the **camera of a mobile device** to scan the code. The associated entry is opened directly in openBIS. Your scanned selection will be saved for future reference. --- graph TB; The process is as follows: Step 1: Select scanning device Step 2: Scan the barcode.', '## Barcodes and QR codes

### Generate batches of barcodes / QR codes

After selecting the desired parameters, click the **Generate Custom
Barcodes** button.

To print the barcodes use the **print icon** on the form, next to
**Generate Custom Barcodes/QR Codes**. These barcodes can be printed on labels to
be attached to vials. When the samples are registered in openBIS, these
barcodes can be scanned and assigned to the samples as explained above.



### Scan barcodes from mobile devicesIt is also possible to scan barcodes and QR codes using the scan button
on top of the main menu, as shown below. In this way, you can scan a
barcode or QR code already associated with an entry and this will open
the entry page in openBIS. You can use a scanner or the camera of a
mobile device. The selection you make is saved.

![](../../_images/scan-barcode-navigation-menu-1-1024x241.png)

Updated on July 5, 2023', '## üì• Step 4: Print and Apply Stickers - Use durable stickers compatible with your printer - Include optional metadata (e.g., contact, organizational unit) - Apply to physical objects clearly and accessibly --- ### How to print Code from openBIS(tbL) - Print Barcode/QR code generated in openBIS ## üì° Step 5: Scan and Use in openBIS - Use barcode/QR readers (USB-HID or Bluetooth) - Scanned codes will: - Display object info - Link samples/devices in experiments > üß™ Example Use Case: Scan a sample‚Äôs QR code during an experiment to auto-link it to the experiment record in openBIS. ---', "## \U0001faaa Step 1: Understand Default Barcode Behavior - When an object is registered in openBIS, a **default barcode** is automatically generated. - This barcode is visible in the **Identification Info** section. - If it's not visible: - Click the **More** drop-down menu. - Select **Show Identification Info**. ---", '## ‚úÖ Prerequisites - Access to an openBIS instance - Physical objects to label (e.g., samples, devices) - Barcode/QR code reader (USB or Bluetooth) - Sticker printer or external code generator (optional) ---']
response:
To scan barcodes or QR codes in openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Access the Barcode Tool**: In the top **Main menu**, click the **Barcode** icon.  
2. **Choose Your Scanner**: Use a dedicated **barcode scanner** or the **camera of a mobile device** to scan the code.  
3. **Scan the Code**: Point the scanner or camera at the barcode/QR code. The associated entry in openBIS will open directly.  
4. **Save Your Selection**: The scanned code is saved for future reference.  

This method works for both pre-generated barcodes (e.g., on labels) and custom codes created in openBIS. Scanning links the physical object to its digital record, making it easy to associate samples, devices, or other entities with experiments or datasets. For example, scanning a sample‚Äôs QR code during an experiment automatically links it to the experiment record.  

If the barcode isn‚Äôt visible in the **Identification Info** section, click **More > Show Identification Info** to display it.
reference: In the top Main menu next to the Global Search field, click on the Barcode icon. Use a barcode scanner or the camera of a mobile device to scan the code. The associated entry is opened directly in openBIS. Your scanned selection will be saved for future reference.

user_input: How do you search for Datasets in the ELN?
retrieved_contexts:
['To use a saved search query in the ELN, navigate to the left main menu, open the **Utilities** drop-down menu and select ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Advanced Search Step 2: Open the top drop-down menu of the Advanced Search form Step 3: Select stored search Step 4: Click on Search icon.', '## How to use the Data Store - main functions for Users ### How to start - [Log in to the BAM Data Store - main instance](How_to_log_in) - [Represent research data - Conceptual data model](Represent_research_data) - [Manage Access to Spaces and Projects](Manage_Access) ### Register data in the *Lab Notebook* - [Register a Project](Register_project) - [Register Collection of the type Default Experiment](Register_default_Experiment) - [Register non-sequential Experimental Steps](Register_non-seq_Experimental_Step) - [Register sequential Experimental Steps](Register_seq_Experimental_Step) - [Upload data](Upload_data) ### Connect Experimental Steps in the *Lab Notebook* - [Define Parents and Children of Experimental Steps](Parents_and_Children_Experimental_Steps) - [Display connections of Experimental Steps - Hierarchy Graph](Hierarchy_graph) - [Add multiple Children to an Experimental Steps - Children generator](Children_generator) ### Edit, Delete and Move functions - [Project Overview](Project_overview) - [Edit Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Edit_ELN) - [Delete Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Delete_ELN) - [Revert deletions of Collection, Objects and Datasets](Revert_deletions_ELN) - [Move Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Move_ELN) - [Move Experimental Step - Object with descendants](Move_with_descendants_ELN) - [History of Changes](History_ELN) ### Additional Function - [Embedding Images in Text Fields](Embedding_Images) - [Filter Objects within a Collection](Filter) - [Search - Global and Advanced search across all fields of all Entities](Global_advanced_search) - [Search for: Objects in the Inventory](Search_Inventory) - [Search for: Objects - Experimental Steps in the Lab Notebook and save search queries](Search_Experimental_Steps) - [Use saved search queries](Use_saved_search) - [Search for Datasets](Search_Dataset_Lab_Notebook) ### Additional Function - [Embedding Images in Text Fields](Embedding_Images) - [Filter Objects within a Collection](Filter) - [Search - Global and Advanced search across all fields of all Entities](Global_advanced_search) - [Search for: Objects in the Inventory](Search_Inventory) - [Search for: Objects - Experimental Steps in the Lab Notebook and save search queries](Search_Experimental_Steps) - [Use saved search queries](Use_saved_search) - [Search for Datasets](Search_Dataset_Lab_Notebook)', 'Tutorial 2: Regester data in ELN In this step-by-step video tutorial, you will get familiar with the BAM Data Store and its key components: - **Overview of Data Store** ‚Äì Understand the structure and functionality of the BAM Data Store. - **Overview of BAM Inventory** ‚Äì Learn how to manage and track inventory efficiently. - **Overview of ELN** ‚Äì Get introduced to the Electronic Lab Notebook (ELN) and its features. - **Role and Rights** ‚Äì Discover the responsibilities and permissions of Data Store users.', '## Group ELN Settings

1. Show the dataset archiving buttons for the group. Please note
   that this is not available by default, but the infrastructure
   for [archiving to
   tapes](../../general-users/data-archiving.html)
   (StrongBox/StrongLink) needs to be put in place ([Multi data set
   archiving](#../../../uncategorized/multi-data-set-archiving.md))\*.
2. Hide sections by default. By default some sections in some forms
   are hidden:

1. Description in *Spaces* and *Projects*.
2. Identification info in *Spaces*, *Projects*, *Experiments*,
   *Objects*, *Datasets*.

By unchecking this option, these sections will be shown by default.

Updated on April 26, 2023', '## Advanced search

### Search for: Dataset

1. **All**: search across all fields of all Datasets
2. **Property**: can select one or more specific properties to search
   on. These can be selected in the **Field Name** (see above)
3. **Object**: search for Datasets in a given Object
4. **Experiment/Collection**: search for Datasets in a given
   Experiment/Collection

![image info](../../_images/adv-search-datasets-1024x349.png)

Also in this case, fields can be excluded from the search by selecting
the NOT checkbox in the table.



### Search for: specific Object Type (e.g Experimental Step)In this case, the available Field Types are the same as when searching
for an Object.

Available **Field Types**:']
response:
To search for **Datasets** in the **ELN (Electronic Lab Notebook)**, follow these steps:  

1. **Access Advanced Search**:  
   - Navigate to the **Utilities** dropdown menu in the left main menu.  
   - Select **Advanced Search** to open the search form.  

2. **Choose Search Scope**:  
   - For **Datasets**, select the **"All"** option to search across all fields of all Datasets.  
   - Alternatively, use the **"Property"** filter to specify one or more specific properties (e.g., metadata fields) to narrow the search.  

3. **Refine by Object or Experiment/Collection**:  
   - If needed, filter Datasets by a specific **Object** (e.g., an Experimental Step) or **Experiment/Collection**. This helps locate Datasets tied to particular experiments or organizational units.  

4. **Exclude Fields (Optional)**:  
   - Use the **"NOT"** checkbox in the search form to exclude certain fields from the search if desired.  

5. **Execute the Search**:  
   - Click the **Search icon** to retrieve results.  

6. **Save the Search (Optional)**:  
   - If you want to reuse this query later, save it as a **saved search** under the **"Use saved search queries"** option.  

This process allows you to efficiently locate Datasets within the ELN, whether you're searching broadly or targeting specific experiments, objects, or metadata fields. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example of a saved search query!
reference: To search through Datasets, navigate to main menu on the left side, open the Utilities drop-down menu and select Advanced Search . In the Search For drop-down menu, select the Dataset option and select the AND operator to add additional search parameters. For example, to search for a Dataset by the name of the Registrator, select the option Property in the drop-down menu under Field Type ; the option Registrator [ATTR.REGISTRATOR] under Field Name , and the option thatEqualsUserId (UserId) from the Comparator Operator . To define the search value, start typing the Name of the Registrator in the Field Value and click on the Search icon, next to the operator field Using (e.g., AND) to activate the search.

To save the search, click Save. Saved searchers are available in the drop-down menu displayed at the top of the Advanced Search page.", 'To search for Objects, navigate to the left menu, open the **Utilities** drop-down menu and select ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Advanced Search Step 2: Click on Search For Step 3: Select operator from Using drop-down menu (e.g., AND) Step 4: Select Field Value option (e.g., Instrument) Step 5: Click on the + icon Step 6: Select Field Type option (e.g., Property) Step 7: Enter Field Name and Field Value if available Step 8: Click on the search icon.', '## Advanced search

### Search for: specific Object Type (e.g Experimental Step)

1. **All**: search across all fields of the specific Object type (e.g.
   Experimental Step)
2. **Property**: can select one or more specific properties to search
   on. These can be selected in the **Field Name** (see above)
3. **Experiment/Collection**: search for Objects of the selected type
   in a given Experiment/Collection
4. **Parent**: search for Objects of the selected type that have the
   specified parents
5. **Children**: search for Objects of the selected type that have the
   specified children

![image info](../../_images/adv-search-exp-step-1024x366.png)

Collection from a Collection page, by selecting **Search in Collection**

Navigate to the relevant Default Experiment and select the + New tab. From the Select an Object Type drop-down menu, select Experimental Step. Step 2: Complete the Experimental Step Form Fill out the New Experimental Step form. To display the Identification Info, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info, if it is not already visible. The Code is automatically generated and can only be modified during the registration process. Assign a meaningful Name to the Experimental Step, as this name will be displayed to users. Please review all entries carefully before saving. ‚öóÔ∏è Note: The new Experimental Step will be organized at the same hierarchical level as other Objects in the left-hand menu of the Laboratory Notebook.']
response:
To perform an advanced search for **Experimental Steps**, follow these steps:  

1. **Access Advanced Search**:  
   - Navigate to the **Utilities** dropdown menu in the Lab Notebook and select **Advanced Search**.  

2. **Define Search Parameters**:  
   - Under the **Search For** dropdown, select **Experiment/Collection**.  
   - Choose an operator (e.g., **AND**) from the **Using** dropdown menu to refine your search logic.  

3. **Specify Search Fields**:  
   - Select **Field Type** (e.g., **All** to search across all fields of the Experimental Step or **Property** to focus on specific attributes like "Modification Date").  
   - Enter the **Field Value** (e.g., a username, keyword, or date). For date-based searches, use the **calendar icon** to select a date and choose a comparator like **thatISLaterThan**.  

4. **Refine with Parent/Child Relationships**:  
   - If needed, use the **+** icon to add additional filters. For example, search for Experimental Steps with specific **parents** or **children** by selecting the **Parent** or **Children** option under **Field Type**.  

5. **Save Your Search (Optional)**:  
   - To save the query for later use, click the **Save** icon at the top of the Advanced Search form. Name your search and optionally link it to a Collection for easy access.  

6. **Execute the Search**:  
   - Click the **Search** icon to retrieve results.  

This method allows you to efficiently locate Experimental Steps based on criteria like metadata, relationships, or dates, while leveraging the Lab Notebook‚Äôs powerful search tools. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example!
reference: Open the Utilities drop-down menu and select Advanced Search . Click on Search For drop-down menu and select Experiment/Collection, select an operator from the Using drop-down menu (e.g., AND), select Field Type option (e.g., All), enter Field Value (e.g., your BAM username to search for all Collections you have registered). Click the + icon to narrow the search further, select Field Type option (e.g., Property) and Field Name option (e.g., Modification Date. A list of all available properties becomes available), enter option for a Comparator Operator (e.g., thatISLaterThan (Date)) and select the date in calendar icon. Click on the Search icon to activate the search. Search values can also be excluded from the search by selection the NOT checkbox.
