response:
To search for Objects in the Inventory, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Utilities Menu**: In the left-hand menu, locate and open the **Utilities** drop-down.  
2. **Select Advanced Search**: Choose the **Advanced Search** option to access the search interface.  
3. **Choose Search Scope**:  
   - For general searches, select **"All"** to search across all fields of the Objects.  
   - For targeted searches, use **"Property"** to specify particular fields (e.g., Instrument, Code) or **"Experiment/Collection"** to filter by a specific context.  
4. **Define Search Criteria**:  
   - Click the **+** icon to add search conditions.  
   - Select the **Field Type** (e.g., Property) and enter the **Field Name** and **Field Value** (e.g., "Instrument" with a specific name).  
   - Use the **NOT** checkbox to exclude certain fields if needed.  
5. **Execute the Search**: Click the **search icon** to retrieve results.  

This method allows you to efficiently locate Objects based on your specific needs, whether you‚Äôre filtering by properties, relationships, or broader criteria. Let me know if you‚Äôd like help refining the search further!
reference: To search for Objects, navigate to the left menu, open the Utilities drop-down menu and select Advanced Search . Click on Search For drop-down menu and select Experiment/Collection; select an operator (e.g., AND) from the Using drop-down menu. Select the Field Type option (e.g., All), enter a Field Value (e.g., Instrument). Click the + icon to narrow the search further, select Field Type option (e.g., Property). Select one of the displayed values in the Field Name and enter a value in the Field Value . Click on the Search icon to activate the search. Search values can also be excluded by selecting the NOT checkbox.

user_input: What does the guide on sharing code in BAM Research GitHub cover?
retrieved_contexts: ['This guide walks you through the steps to share your code (scripts, parsers, tools, etc.) in the [BAM research GitHub organization](https://github.com/BAMresearch), following [open-source best practices](https://github.com/BAMresearch/.oss). ## ‚úÖ Prerequisites - You have a GitHub account. - You are a member of the [BAM research GitHub organization](https://github.com/BAMresearch). > For access please contact jose.pizarro-blanco@bam.de via Microsoft Teams with your GitHub username to request an invitation.{.is-info}', '## Two options to Share Your Code ### Option A: Create a New Repository 1. Go to the [BAM research GitHub organization](https://github.com/orgs/BAMresearch/repositories). 2. Click **"New repository"**. 3. Fill in the repository details: - **Name**: Choose a clear, descriptive name. - **Description**: Briefly explain what the code does. - **Visibility**: Choose **Public** (preferred for OSS) or **Private**. 4. Click **Create repository**. ### Option B: Copy an Existing Repository If your code already exists elsewhere: - **[Fork it](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/fork-a-repo)**: If the original repository is public and has a compatible license: - Go to the original repo and click **Fork** ‚Üí Choose **BAM research** as the destination. - **[Duplicate it](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/duplicating-a-repository)**: If forking isn‚Äôt suitable: 1. Clone the original repo locally. 2. Create a new repo under BAM research. 3. Push the code to the new repo.', 'Here you find "How do I ‚Ä¶?" related to functions of the BAM Data Store and its underlying software openBIS. Goal-oriented instructions should help you accomplish specific tasks. If the function you are looking for is missing, please contact the Data Store Team at datastore@bam.de. How to start Log in to the BAM Data Store openBIS Data Structure Manage Access to Spaces and Project', 'Tutorial 8: Barcodes In this step-by-step video tutorial, you will get familiar with the BAM Data Store and its key components: - **Overview of Data Store** ‚Äì Understand the structure and functionality of the BAM Data Store. - **Overview of BAM Inventory** ‚Äì Learn how to manage and track inventory efficiently. - **Overview of ELN** ‚Äì Get introduced to the Electronic Lab Notebook (ELN) and its features. - **Role and Rights** ‚Äì Discover the responsibilities and permissions of Data Store users.', 'üìñ How-to guides Step-by-step instructions for openBIS functions. Go to Guides ‚ùì FAQ Frequently asked questions about Data Store and openBIS. View FAQ üë• Use cases Discover Use cases of the Data Store. Discover Use cases # What is the Data Store? **The Data Store is the central system for research data management (RDM) at BAM.**']
response: The guide on sharing code in the BAM Research GitHub organization covers two main approaches: creating a new repository or copying an existing one. It walks you through steps like setting up a repository with a clear name and description, choosing visibility (public or private), and configuring settings for open-source best practices. If your code already exists elsewhere, the guide explains how to fork a public repository (if licensed compatibly) or duplicate it under the BAM research organization. Prerequisites include having a GitHub account and being a member of the BAM research organization‚Äîcontact jose.pizarro-blanco@bam.de for access if needed.
reference: This guide walks you through the steps to share your code (scripts, parsers, tools, etc.) in the BAM research GitHub organization, following open-source best practices.

user_input: How do you share and grant access to ELN Projects?
retrieved_contexts:
['Users can manage access in their ELN - My Space at the Space and Project levels (access will apply to underlying contents: Collections/Objects/Datasets). To grant access to a Project, navigate to relevant Project, click on the More tab and open the dropdown Menu, select Manage access to open the from. Select Role , enter the Username (B The process is as follows: Step 1: More dropdown menu Step 2: Manage access Step 3: Select ‚ÄúRole‚Äù Step 4: Enter BAM username Step 5: Grant access', 'Users have Admin rights in their ELN Space-My Space by default. This allows them to manage access rights at the level of Space and Project. Changes apply to underlying contents (Collections, Objects and Datasets); download Datasets and save searches.', 'To embed an image (.jpeg, .png formats) in the description of the Entity during the editing, drag an image in the description field. The process is as follows: Step 1: Click Upload button Step 2: Select ELN Preview in the Dataset Type (*) Step 3: Select files to upload Step 4: Review the files and Save.', '## Register ProjectsIn a personal folder, users can register one or more *Projects* they
currently work on. *Projects* in openBIS only have a **Description**
field, no additional fields can be added.

1. Navigate to the relevant *Space* in the *Lab Notebook* menu and click the **+ New Project**
   ![image info](../../_images/ELN-new-project.png)
2. Should you have an empty page, select **Show Identification Info** and **Show Description** from the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown
3. *Projects* do not have a **Name** field, but only **Code**. Codes can only take alphanumeric characters and no spaces. Codes are prettified in the Main Menu.
4. Enter a **Description** for the project.
5. Click **Save** on top of the form.

![image info](../../_images/ELN-create-project.png)

In the **More‚Ä¶** dropdown you have additional options on what you can do
in the Project folder, as shown below.

![image info](../../_images/project-more-dropdown.png)', '# General Overview

**Data** of any sort can be attached to the corresponding Experimental
step in different ways, depending on the size.

Data can be exported to data repositories, such as
[Zenodo](https://zenodo.org/) or the [ETH Research
Collection](https://www.research-collection.ethz.ch/) (for ETHZ users
only).

This allows to have the complete overview of workflows and information,
from initial data generation to data analysis and publication.

The openBIS ELN interface can be accessed via a URL of this type:
**https://openbis-xxx/openbis/webapp/eln-lims/**

where *openbis-xxx* is the name of the server specified in the openBIS
configuration file, during the installation by a system admin.']
response:
To share and grant access to an ELN Project, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Project**: Go to the specific ELN Project you want to manage.  
2. **Open the Manage Access Menu**: Click the **More** tab, then select **Manage access** from the dropdown menu.  
3. **Select a Role**: Choose the appropriate role for the user (e.g., Viewer, Editor, etc.).  
4. **Enter the BAM Username**: Input the BAM username of the person you want to grant access to.  
5. **Grant Access**: Confirm the action to assign the selected role and permissions.  

By default, users have **Admin rights** in their ELN Space, allowing them to manage access at both the Space and Project levels. These permissions apply to all underlying content, such as Collections, Objects, and Datasets. If you need to share a Project, ensure the recipient‚Äôs BAM username is correctly entered and the role aligns with their access needs. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example of a role configuration!
reference: Users can manage access in their ELN - My Space at the Space and Project levels (access will apply to underlying contents: Collections/Objects/Datasets). To grant access to a Project, navigate to relevant Project, click on the More tab and open the dropdown Menu, select Manage access to open the from. Select Role , enter the Username (BAM username  lower case only) and Group (FB). Click Grant access to apply settings.

user_input: How do you enable the Storage Widget for a specific Object Type?
retrieved_contexts:
['The Storage Widget is disabled by default. To track storage positions for a particular Object Type, the storage must be enabled by a group The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Settings Step 2: Select division number Step 3: Click on Edit tab Step 4: Scroll down to Object Type definitions Extension Step 5: Select an Object type Step 6: Enable Storage Step 7: Review the entries and Save.', '## Enable Storage Widget on Sample FormsWhen a new *Object type* is created by an *Instance admin* (see [New Entity Type Registration)](new-entity-type-registration.html), the storage widget is disabled by default.

If we want to track storage positions for this particular *Object type* as described in [Allocate storage positions to samples](../../general-users/managing-storage-of-samples.html#allocate-storage-positions-to-samples), the **Storage** should be enabled in the **Settings**, under **Utilities**. This can be done by a *group admin*.

For this, follow the steps below:

1. Go to **Settings**, under **Utilities**
2. Click the **Edit** button
3. Scroll to the last section of the Settings: **Object Type definitions Extension**
4. Open the *Object type* for which you want to enable the storage, e.g. **Sample**
5. Select **Enable Storage**
6. Save

![image info](../../../_images/settings-enable-storage-1024x509.png)', '## Add metadata to Storage PositionsStorage positions by default have the following metadata:

1. Storage code
2. Storage rack row
3. Storage rack column
4. Box name
5. Box size
6. Box position
7. User id

It is possible to add additional information. This can be done by an
*Instance Admin* by editing the *Object* Type **STORAGE\_POSITION** in
the admin interface (see [New Entity Type Registration](new-entity-type-registration.html)).', '## Allocate storage positions to samples

### Register storage position for a single sample

2. In the widget that opens, select the appropriate **Storage** from the
   dropdown menu. Storage must be configured by a lab manager or group
   admin as explained in [Configure Lab
   Storages](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/customise-inventory-of-materials-and-samples.html#configure-lab-storage)

![image info](../../_images/storage-selection-1024x202.png)

3. Select the **position** in the storage (shelf and rack).

4. If the sample is in a box, provide a **Box Name.**

5. Select the **Box Size** form the list of configured sizes (the list
can be configured by an *Instance Admin)*.

6. Select the **Position** in the box.

7. Click **Accept.**

![image info](../../_images/storage-assign-positions-1024x355.png)

#### Add additional metadata to storage positions', '## Register a new Object Type1. Select **Types -> Object Types** from the menu.
2. Click **Add** at the bottom of the page.

![](../../../_images/add-object-type-1024x382.png)

![](../../../_images/add-new-object-type-1024x539.png)']
response:
To enable the Storage Widget for a specific Object Type in openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to Settings**: Go to the **Settings** section under **Utilities**.  
2. **Edit Configuration**: Click the **Edit** button to modify the settings.  
3. **Locate Object Type Definitions**: Scroll to the **Object Type definitions Extension** section.  
4. **Select the Object Type**: Choose the specific Object Type for which you want to enable storage tracking (e.g., "Sample").  
5. **Enable Storage**: Check the **Enable Storage** option for that Object Type.  
6. **Save Changes**: Review the settings and click **Save** to apply the changes.  

This process must be performed by a **group admin** or **instance admin** to ensure the Storage Widget is activated for the desired Object Type. Once enabled, users can assign storage positions to samples or materials through the widget. Let me know if you need further details!
reference: The Storage Widget is disabled by default. To track storage positions for a particular Object Type, the storage must be enabled by a group Admin (Data Store Steward). To do this, navigate to the left main menu, under Utilities select Settings and your division number drop-down menu. Click on the Edit tab and scroll down to the Object Type definitions Extension section, choose the Object type, and check the Enable Storage checkbox. Review the entries and Save .

user_input: How do you create Templates for Objects?
retrieved_contexts:
['# Create Templates for ObjectsIt is possible to create templates for *Objects*. Templates are useful
when one has to register repetitive *Experimental steps* or
*measurements* where some fields should always be pre-defined.

For each *Object* type several templates can be created. This can be
done by the lab manager, who should have admin rights for editing the
**Settings**. It is not necessary to be *Instance admin* for this. In a
multi-group set up, this can be done by the *group admin*.

Procedure:

1. Go to the **Settings**, under **Utilities**
2. Scroll down to the **Templates** section
3. From the **New Template** tab select select the *Object type* for
   which you want to have a template.

![image info](../../../_images/settings-create-template-1-1-1024x413.png)

![image info](../../../_images/settings-create-templates-2.png)

1. Fill in the fields as desired.
2. **Save.**

Your templates will be show in the table in the **Templates** section,
as shown below', "To create a Template for an Object type, navigate to left main menu and select **Utilities**, and then **Settings**. A Select Group Settings drop-down menu will appear, select your **division number** to open your group settings. Click on the **Edit** tab, open the Templates section, click on the **+ New Template** tab. Select an Object Type for which the template is intended, e.g. Experimental Step. Fill out the predefined values as required, review the entries and **Save**. All available templates to your group are displayed in the Templates section. > Note, using a Template will overwrite the existing parent(s) and child(ren) defined in the registration form of the *Object*. When registering [sequential Experimental Steps](/en/How_to_guides/Register_seq_Experimental_Step) using a Template, you must ***explicitly specify the parent(s) and/or child(ren) during the registration*** process. If the parent(s) and child(ren) are fixed for a particular Template, they can be defined at the time of the Template's creation. In such cases, they will be automatically applied whenever the Template is used.{.is-info}", '# Create Templates for Objects

![image info](../../../_images/templates-table-3-1024x493.png)

See [Use template for Experimental Steps](../../general-users/lab-notebook.html#use-templates-for-experimental-steps) for more info on how to use templates.

Updated on April 26, 2023', '## STOCK ORDERS

### Processing product orders from requests

3. If an **order** **template** form is available (see [Create Templates for Objects](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/create-templates-for-objects.html)), this template can be used and most fields will be automatically filled (see [Use templates for Experimental Steps](lab-notebook.html#use-templates-for-experimental-steps)). If no template is available, the relevant fields in the form need to be filled in with the relevant information.

![image info](../../_images/create-new-order.png)

4. Enter the **Order Status.** This field is mandatory. Available options are **Delivered**, **Paid**, **Ordered**, **Not yet ordered**. When you first create the order, you should set the status to **Not yet ordered**.
5. Add one or more requests to the Order. Only requests with Order Status set to **Not yet ordered** will be displayed and can be selected.
6. Click **Save** on top of the form.', '## Register a new Object Type1. Select **Types -> Object Types** from the menu.
2. Click **Add** at the bottom of the page.

![](../../../_images/add-object-type-1024x382.png)

![](../../../_images/add-new-object-type-1024x539.png)']
response:
To create a template for an object in openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Access the Templates Section**:  
   - Navigate to the **Utilities** menu and select **Settings**.  
   - Scroll down to the **Templates** section.  

2. **Select the Object Type**:  
   - Click the **New Template** tab.  
   - Choose the *Object type* for which you want to create the template (e.g., *Experimental Step*, *Order*, or other custom types).  

3. **Define Template Fields**:  
   - Fill in the fields as desired. These predefined values will automatically populate when the template is used later.  
   - For sequential objects (e.g., Experimental Steps), ensure you explicitly specify parent(s) and/or child(ren) during registration, as templates will overwrite existing relationships.  

4. **Save the Template**:  
   - Click **Save** to store the template.  
   - The template will appear in the **Templates** table under your group‚Äôs settings.  

**Notes**:  
- Templates are created by lab managers, group admins, or admins with editing rights.  
- Using a template streamlines repetitive registrations but requires careful setup to avoid unintended data overrides.  

Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example for a specific object type!
reference: To create a Template for an Object type, navigate to left main menu and select Utilities , and then Settings . A Select Group Settings drop-down menu will appear, select your division number to open your group settings. Click on the Edit tab, open the Templates section, click on the + New Template tab. Select an Object Type for which the template is intended, e.g. Experimental Step. Fill out the predefined values as required, review the entries and Save . All available templates to your group are displayed in the Templates section.

user_input: How do you upload data to Experimental Steps or Objects?
retrieved_contexts:
['The data uploaded in openBIS can be of any type and format, individual files, or data sets. Data uploaded is **immutable**, it cannot be changed, if necessary, different versions of the data must be uploaded. In the Data Store, it is suggested to upload data to the Experimental Steps - Objects. To upload data, navigate to relevant Experimental Step and click on the **Upload** tab. In the *Create Dataset* form, enter the Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). Select **Dataset Type** if not defined, e.g. Attachment. Fill out the relevant information and click on select **files to upload**, drag and drop or browse files or upload a zip file (select Uncompress-checkbox before import), review the files and **Save**. Datasets are displayed in the left-lower corner of the main menu. Uploaded Datasets are displayed in the left-hand menu. To view the contents of Datasets, click on the Dataset and download it. Please note that there is no preview function for Datasets in openBIS. Alternatively, you can preview text, images, or tables by registering an Object of type [Entry](/en/How_to_guides/Register_objects_Inventory) or registering an Object using [Templates](/en/How_to_guides/Templates).', '# Data UploadData can be uploaded to Datasets in openBIS to *Experiments* and *Objects* (e.g., *Experimental Steps*). openBIS is agnostic of file formats and types.

Small data files can be uploaded via the web user interface, larger data files can be uploaded via dropbox mechanism.', '## Register Experimental StepsAs mentioned above, the various steps executed when performing an
Experiment in the lab can be registered in openBIS as  *Experimental
Steps or Entries.*

The default *Experimental Step* has pre-defined fields, as shown below:

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2020-02-28-at-15.29.17.png)

An *Entry*, is a blank page, with no pre-defined fields:

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2020-02-28-at-15.29.33.png)

To register a default *Experimental Step* or *Entry*:

1. Navigate to the relevant **Experiment** in the *Lab Notebook* menu and click the **+ New** button, as shown below.
2. Select **Experimental Step** or **Entry**
3. Fill in the relevant information or select an available template from the list (see below).
4. If **Show in project overview** is set to true, this *Experimental Step* or *Entry* will be displayed on the *Project* page.
5. Click **Save** on top of the form.

![image info](../../_images/object-registration-201011.png)', '## Move Experimental StepsTo move an *Experimental Step* to a different *Experiment*, choose
**Move** from the **More..** drop down, as shown in the picture above.

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2021-09-21-at-18.40.02.png)

It is possible to move *Experimental Steps* from the *Object* table
which is presented on an *Experiment* or *Collection* page.

Select the entries to move and use the **Move** button on the table. You
can move to an existing *Experiment*/*Collection* or create a new one.

![image info](../../_images/move-objects-from-object-table-in-collection-1024x527.png)', '## Data upload via web UITo upload data via the web interface:

1.Click the **Upload** button in the form, as shown below.

![image info](../../_images/Screenshot-2022-02-25-at-16.32.27-1024x359.png)

2. Select the dataset type (e.g. Attachment).

3. Fill in the relevant fields in the form. It is advisable to always
enter a **Name**, because this is shown in the menu. If the name is not
provided, the dataset code is shown.

4. Drag and drop files in the **Files** **Uploader** area or browse for
files.

5. When uploading a zip file, the option to **uncompress before
import** will be presented in the form.

6. **Save.**

![image info](../../_images/dataset-upload-UI-1024x951.png)

**Note for MacOS users:** the default MacOS archiver generates hidden
folders that become visible in openBIS upon unarchive. To avoid this
there are two options:']
response:
To upload data to **Experimental Steps** or **Objects** in openBIS, follow these steps:  

1. **Navigate to the Target Location**:  
   - For **Experimental Steps**, go to the relevant *Experiment* in the *Lab Notebook* menu.  
   - For **Objects**, ensure you‚Äôre in the correct *Experiment* or *Collection* where the Object is defined.  

2. **Access the Upload Interface**:  
   - Click the **Upload** tab within the Experimental Step or Object. This opens the *Create Dataset* form.  

3. **Configure the Dataset**:  
   - **Dataset Type**: Select a type (e.g., *Attachment*).  
   - **Identification Info**: Enter a name (this appears in the menu). If omitted, the dataset code is used.  
   - **Files**: Drag and drop files, browse for files, or upload a zip file. If uploading a zip, check the **Uncompress** box to avoid hidden folders (especially for MacOS users).  

4. **Save the Dataset**:  
   - Review the files and click **Save**. The dataset will now appear in the left-hand menu under the relevant Experimental Step or Object.  

5. **View or Manage Data**:  
   - To access the dataset, click its name. Note that there‚Äôs no preview function for files, but text/images/tables can be previewed via registered *Entries* or *Templates*.  

For large files, consider using the **Dropbox mechanism** for uploads. Always ensure datasets are properly labeled for clarity and easy retrieval!
reference: The data uploaded in openBIS can be of any type and format, individual files, or data sets. Data uploaded is immutable , it cannot be changed, if necessary, different versions of the data must be uploaded. In the Data Store, it is suggested to upload data to the Experimental Steps - Objects. To upload data, navigate to relevant Experimental Step and click on the Upload tab. In the Create Dataset form, enter the Identification Info (if hidden, open the More drop-down menu and select Show Identification Info). Select Dataset Type if not defined, e.g. Attachment. Fill out the relevant information and click on select files to upload , drag and drop or browse files or upload a zip file (select Uncompress-checkbox before import), review the files and Save . Datasets are displayed in the left-lower corner of the main menu. Uploaded Datasets are displayed in the left-hand menu. To view the contents of Datasets, click on the Dataset and download it. Please note that there is no preview function for Datasets in openBIS. Alternatively, you can preview text, images, or tables by registering an Object of type Entry or registering an Object using Templates.

user_input: What is the purpose of using barcodes and QR codes in openBIS?
retrieved_contexts:
['## \U0001faaa Step 1: Choose the Code Content When an Object is registered, a Default Barcode is automatically generated by openBIS. This is found in Identification Info. It is also possible to use the PermId to generate a Barcode/QR code. ### Option A: **PermId** - **Pros**: - Always available and unique - Compact (suitable for Micro-QR) - **Cons**: - Tied to one openBIS instance - Changes on export/import - Only available after object registration ### Option B: **$BARCODE Property** - **Pros**: - Can be pre-assigned and batch imported - Compatible across systems - **Cons**: - Uniqueness not enforced - Requires additional data management ---', '## üì• Step 4: Print and Apply Stickers - Use durable stickers compatible with your printer - Include optional metadata (e.g., contact, organizational unit) - Apply to physical objects clearly and accessibly --- ### How to print Code from openBIS(tbL) - Print Barcode/QR code generated in openBIS ## üì° Step 5: Scan and Use in openBIS - Use barcode/QR readers (USB-HID or Bluetooth) - Scanned codes will: - Display object info - Link samples/devices in experiments > üß™ Example Use Case: Scan a sample‚Äôs QR code during an experiment to auto-link it to the experiment record in openBIS. ---', "## \U0001faaa Step 1: Understand Default Barcode Behavior - When an object is registered in openBIS, a **default barcode** is automatically generated. - This barcode is visible in the **Identification Info** section. - If it's not visible: - Click the **More** drop-down menu. - Select **Show Identification Info**. ---", '## ‚úÖ Prerequisites - Access to an openBIS instance - Physical objects to label (e.g., samples, devices) - Barcode/QR code reader (USB or Bluetooth) - Sticker printer or external code generator (optional) ---', '## Barcodes and QR codesThe barcode functionality must be enabled in openBIS by a *lab manager*
or *group admin*: [Enable
Barcodes and QR codes](../general-admin-users/admins-documentation/enable-barcodes.html).



### Barcodes for individual samplesWhen a sample is registered, a barcode is automatically generated by
openBIS. This is found in the **Identification info** section, as shown
below.

![](../../_images/Default-sample-barcode-1.png)

This barcode can be printed and the label can be added to the vial
containing the sample. The option to print the barcode is under the 
**More..** menu

![](../../_images/barcode-print-more-dropdown-slide.png)

If a sample already has its own barcode or QR code, it is possible to scan this with
a scanner or the camera of a mobile device and assign it to the sample.
This can be done after registration of a sample, with the **Custom
Barcode/QR Code Update** option under the **More..** drop down.']
response:
The purpose of using barcodes and QR codes in openBIS is to streamline data management and enhance the traceability of physical objects like samples or devices. Here‚Äôs how they help:  

1. **Unique Identification**: When an object (e.g., a sample) is registered in openBIS, a default barcode is automatically generated. This acts as a unique identifier, making it easy to link physical items to their digital records.  

2. **Quick Access to Information**: Scanning a barcode or QR code displays the object‚Äôs details, such as its name, location, or associated experiment. This saves time and reduces errors during data entry or experimentation.  

3. **Linking to Experiments**: During experiments, scanning a sample‚Äôs barcode automatically connects it to the experiment record in openBIS. This ensures accurate tracking of which samples are used in which experiments.  

4. **Flexibility in Labeling**: Barcodes can be pre-assigned (e.g., for batch imports) or generated dynamically (e.g., using PermId). This flexibility accommodates both small-scale and large-scale workflows.  

5. **Physical Labeling**: Barcodes are printed on durable stickers and applied to physical objects. This makes it easy to locate and manage items in lab environments, even when they‚Äôre stored in containers or cabinets.  

In short, barcodes and QR codes in openBIS bridge the gap between physical objects and digital data, ensuring seamless integration, accuracy, and efficiency in lab workflows. üß™üìä
reference: To enable fast and secure referencing of physical objects (e.g., samples, instruments) in openBIS using barcodes or QR codes.

user_input: How do you access and run saved search queries?
retrieved_contexts: ['To use a saved search query in the ELN, navigate to the left main menu, open the **Utilities** drop-down menu and select ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Advanced Search Step 2: Open the top drop-down menu of the Advanced Search form Step 3: Select stored search Step 4: Click on Search icon.', "Open the **Utilities** drop-down menu and select **Advanced Search**. Click on **Search For** drop-down menu and select Experiment/Collection, select an operator from the **Using** drop-down menu (e.g., AND), select **Field Type** option (e.g., All), enter **Field Value** (e.g., your BAM username to search for all Collections you have registered). Click the **+** icon to narrow the search further, select **Field Type** option (e.g., Property) and **Field Name** option (e.g., Modification Date. A list of all available properties becomes available), enter option for a **Comparator Operator** (e.g., thatISLaterThan (Date)) and select the **date** in **calendar** icon. Click on the **Search** icon to activate the search. Search values can also be excluded from the search by selection the NOT checkbox. To save a search query in your own *Lab Notebook's* Space. Click on the **Save** icon displayed in the upper part of the *Advance Search* form, the **Save Search query** window will open, fill out search **Name** and start typing in the **search entity to store query** to find the name of a **Collection**. To save the search, click Save. Saved searchers are available in the drop-down menu displayed at the top of the Advanced Search page.", '## How to use the Data Store - main functions for Users ### How to start - [Log in to the BAM Data Store - main instance](How_to_log_in) - [Represent research data - Conceptual data model](Represent_research_data) - [Manage Access to Spaces and Projects](Manage_Access) ### Register data in the *Lab Notebook* - [Register a Project](Register_project) - [Register Collection of the type Default Experiment](Register_default_Experiment) - [Register non-sequential Experimental Steps](Register_non-seq_Experimental_Step) - [Register sequential Experimental Steps](Register_seq_Experimental_Step) - [Upload data](Upload_data) ### Connect Experimental Steps in the *Lab Notebook* - [Define Parents and Children of Experimental Steps](Parents_and_Children_Experimental_Steps) - [Display connections of Experimental Steps - Hierarchy Graph](Hierarchy_graph) - [Add multiple Children to an Experimental Steps - Children generator](Children_generator) ### Edit, Delete and Move functions - [Project Overview](Project_overview) - [Edit Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Edit_ELN) - [Delete Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Delete_ELN) - [Revert deletions of Collection, Objects and Datasets](Revert_deletions_ELN) - [Move Projects, Collections, Objects and Datasets](Move_ELN) - [Move Experimental Step - Object with descendants](Move_with_descendants_ELN) - [History of Changes](History_ELN) ### Additional Function - [Embedding Images in Text Fields](Embedding_Images) - [Filter Objects within a Collection](Filter) - [Search - Global and Advanced search across all fields of all Entities](Global_advanced_search) - [Search for: Objects in the Inventory](Search_Inventory) - [Search for: Objects - Experimental Steps in the Lab Notebook and save search queries](Search_Experimental_Steps) - [Use saved search queries](Use_saved_search) - [Search for Datasets](Search_Dataset_Lab_Notebook) ### Additional Function - [Embedding Images in Text Fields](Embedding_Images) - [Filter Objects within a Collection](Filter) - [Search - Global and Advanced search across all fields of all Entities](Global_advanced_search) - [Search for: Objects in the Inventory](Search_Inventory) - [Search for: Objects - Experimental Steps in the Lab Notebook and save search queries](Search_Experimental_Steps) - [Use saved search queries](Use_saved_search) - [Search for Datasets](Search_Dataset_Lab_Notebook)', 'To search across all database fields, enter the search term in the **Global Search** window in the top left-hand corner of the main menu. The ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Advanced Search Step 2: Add Filters and Conditions; Search For drop-down menu and the AND or OR operator Step 3: Select an option from the Field Type menu Step 4: Fill out additional search parameters Step 5: Click the + icon to narrow down the search Step 6: Click on search icon.', 'To search through Datasets, navigate to main menu on the left side, open the **Utilities** drop-down menu and select ** The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Advanced Search Step 2: Select Dataset in the Search For drop-down menu Step 3: Select AND operator in the Using drop-down menu Step 4: Select Property in the drop-down menu under Field Type Step 5: Select Registrator [ATTR.REGISTRATOR] under Field Name Step 6: Select thatEqualsUserId (UserId) from the Comparator Operator Step 7: Start typing the Name of the Registrator in the Field Value Step 8: Click on Search icon.']
response:
To access and run saved search queries in the BAM Data Store or Lab Notebook:  

1. **Navigate to Advanced Search**:  
   - Go to the left main menu, open the **Utilities** drop-down menu, and select **Advanced Search**.  

2. **Select a Saved Search**:  
   - At the top of the Advanced Search form, locate the drop-down menu (labelled "Search For" or "Stored Search" depending on the context).  
   - Choose the saved search query you want to use from the list of available options.  

3. **Execute the Search**:  
   - Click the **Search** icon (usually a magnifying glass or "Search" button) to run the query.  

**Note**: Saved searches are typically stored in your Lab Notebook‚Äôs Space and can be accessed directly from this menu. If you need to save a new search, use the **Save** icon in the Advanced Search form to store it for future use. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example of how to save a search!
reference: To use a saved search query in the ELN, navigate to the left main menu, open the Utilities drop-down menu and select Advanced Search . Open the top drop-down menu of the Advanced Search form, select stored search and click on the Search icon to activate the search.

user_input: How do you verify that a storage position was registered correctly?
retrieved_contexts:
['The Storage Widget is disabled by default. To track storage positions for a particular Object Type, the storage must be enabled by a group The process is as follows: Step 1: Select Settings Step 2: Select division number Step 3: Click on Edit tab Step 4: Scroll down to Object Type definitions Extension Step 5: Select an Object type Step 6: Enable Storage Step 7: Review the entries and Save.', '## Add metadata to Storage PositionsStorage positions by default have the following metadata:

1. Storage code
2. Storage rack row
3. Storage rack column
4. Box name
5. Box size
6. Box position
7. User id

It is possible to add additional information. This can be done by an
*Instance Admin* by editing the *Object* Type **STORAGE\_POSITION** in
the admin interface (see [New Entity Type Registration](new-entity-type-registration.html)).', '## Allocate storage positions to samples

### Batch register storage positions

An example file can be found
here: [SAMPLE-STORAGE\_POSITION-template](../../_downloads/8876503dbbe4fa8ebd95c115324e9367/SAMPLE-STORAGE_POSITION-template.xlsx)

Updated on April 26, 2023', '## Configure Lab Storage

1. **Rack validation**. The position in the shelf and rack needs to be specified.
2. **Box validation**. In addition to **a**, a box name needs to be specified.
3. **Box position validation**. In addition to **a** and **b**, the position in the box needs to be specified.', '## Allocate storage positions to samples

### Batch register storage positions

Storage positions are modelled in openBIS as children of other entries.
To register the positions for several samples with the Batch
Registration using the .tsv template, first the parent samples need to
be registered in openBIS. In a second step, the positions are assigned.

To assign storage positions in batch mode follow the steps below:

> 1. Select **Storage positions** from the **Batch Registration** drop
>    down menu.
> 2. Download the **template file**.
> 3. Remove the **identifier** column from the file (identifiers need
>    to be automatically generated by openBIS).
> 4. Fill in the **parents** column. These are the identifiers of the
>    samples for which we want to register the storage
>    positions(/MATERIALS/PROJECT/OBJECT\_CODE).
> 5. Fill the remaining information about the storage positions.
> 6. Save the file and upload with the **Batch Registration**.']
response:
To verify that a storage position was registered correctly, follow these steps based on openBIS processes:  

1. **Check Metadata Completeness**: Ensure all required metadata fields (e.g., storage code, rack row/column, box name, box position) are populated. Missing or incomplete data may indicate an error.  
2. **Validate Against Rules**: Confirm the storage position adheres to validation rules, such as:  
   - Rack and box positions must follow the lab‚Äôs defined structure (e.g., valid rack rows/columns).  
   - Box positions must align with the box size (e.g., a box labeled "Size 96" cannot have a position beyond 96 wells).  
3. **Confirm Sample Linkage**: Verify the storage position is correctly linked to its parent sample(s) via the "parents" field in batch registration.  
4. **Review System Logs**: If using batch registration, check for system feedback or error messages during upload, which may highlight discrepancies.  
5. **Admin Audit**: An *Instance Admin* can manually review the **STORAGE_POSITION** object type in the admin interface to confirm entries are properly registered and compliant with custom configurations.  

If these checks pass, the storage position is likely registered correctly. Let me know if you need help with specific validation rules or templates!
reference: To verify whether the storage position was registered correctly, select Storage Manager from the Utilities drop-down menu on the left. Select the Storage where the Object was registered from the Storage drop-down menu. The contents of the Storage (e.g.,rack and boxes) are displayed. Double click on the box to display the registered Objects. Place the mouse over the Object of interest to display the corresponding metadata fields and click on the Object name displayed in blue to open the Object form.{.is-info}

user_input: What information is found in the 'How do I?' guides?
retrieved_contexts: ['Here you find "How do I ‚Ä¶?" related to functions of the BAM Data Store and its underlying software openBIS. Goal-oriented instructions should help you accomplish specific tasks. If the function you are looking for is missing, please contact the Data Store Team at datastore@bam.de. How to start Log in to the BAM Data Store openBIS Data Structure Manage Access to Spaces and Project', 'Here you find an answer to "How do I ‚Ä¶?" related questions on how to use the BAM Data Store and its underlying software - openBIS. These goal-oriented instructions should help you accomplish specific tasks. If the function you are looking for is missing, please contact the Data Store Team at datastore@bam.de.', 'Here you will find step-by-step video tutorials to help you learn how to use the BAM Data Store effectively. These tutorials provide hands-on guidance, walking you through key processes to build your knowledge and skills. If you need a tutorial on a specific topic that is not covered, please contact the Data Store Team for support: datastore@bam.de. Tutorial 1: Overview of the Data Store In this step-by-step video tutorial, you will get familiar with the BAM Data Store and its key components: - **Overview of Data Store** ‚Äì Understand the structure and functionality of the BAM Data Store. - **Overview of BAM Inventory** ‚Äì Learn how to manage and track inventory efficiently. - **Overview of ELN** ‚Äì Get introduced to the Electronic Lab Notebook (ELN) and its features. - **Role and Rights** ‚Äì Discover the responsibilities and permissions of Data Store users.', 'Tutorial 8: Barcodes In this step-by-step video tutorial, you will get familiar with the BAM Data Store and its key components: - **Overview of Data Store** ‚Äì Understand the structure and functionality of the BAM Data Store. - **Overview of BAM Inventory** ‚Äì Learn how to manage and track inventory efficiently. - **Overview of ELN** ‚Äì Get introduced to the Electronic Lab Notebook (ELN) and its features. - **Role and Rights** ‚Äì Discover the responsibilities and permissions of Data Store users.', 'üìñ How-to guides Step-by-step instructions for openBIS functions. Go to Guides ‚ùì FAQ Frequently asked questions about Data Store and openBIS. View FAQ üë• Use cases Discover Use cases of the Data Store. Discover Use cases # What is the Data Store? **The Data Store is the central system for research data management (RDM) at BAM.**']
response:
The **"How do I?" guides** are instructional resources designed to help users accomplish specific tasks within the BAM Data Store and its underlying software, openBIS. They provide **goal-oriented, step-by-step instructions** for functions such as:  
- Managing access to spaces and projects  
- Navigating the Data Store interface  
- Using the Electronic Lab Notebook (ELN)  
- Handling inventory management  
- Understanding user roles and permissions  

If a particular function or task isn‚Äôt covered in the guides, the documentation explicitly directs users to contact the **Data Store Team** at `datastore@bam.de` for further assistance. These guides are focused on practical, task-based guidance rather than theoretical explanations.
reference: Here you find an answer to "How do I ?" related questions on how to use the BAM Data Store and its underlying software - openBIS. These goal-oriented instructions should help you accomplish specific tasks. If the function you are looking for is missing, please contact the Data Store Team at datastore@bam.de.

user_input: What are the best practices for defining Masterdata?
retrieved_contexts: ['# Best Practices for Masterdata Definition To ensure a consistent set of [Masterdata](/en/concepts#masterdata) in the BAM Data Store, we are introducing some rules, naming conventions, and recommendations when creating *Spaces*, *Projects*, entity types (*Collection*, *Object*, *Dataset*, and *Property* types) and controlled vocabularies. > In general, Masterdata should be **as generic as possible and as specific as necessary**. It is encouraged to re-use existing entity types and vocabularies from other groups. For this reason, the use of division-specific information in the codes and labels of entity types (e.g., "BAM_FBX.Y_ROOM_TEMPERATURE") should be avoided. {.is-info}', 'Masterdata defintion in the BAM Data Store: - [The Process of Masterdata Definition](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata) - [Best Practices for Masterdata Definition](/en/masterdata_definition/best_practices) - [Masterdata checker](https://mdc.datastore.bam.de/) - [How to use Masterdata checker](/en/masterdata_definition/masterdata_checker) - [The Process of Masterdata Definition for phase 4](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata_for_phase4)', '# The Process of Masterdata Definition Only instance admins can register [Masterdata](/en/concepts#masterdata) in openBIS. Since Data Store Stewards (DSSt) have group admin but not instance admin rights in the `main` Data Store instance, they cannot register domain/division-specific Masterdata on their own. They can use one of the Masterdata Excel templates. To create an Object Type e.g., [Instrument](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata#a-masterdata-excel-template-example) or a Controlled Vocabulary e.g., [DFG_DEVICE_CODE](/masterdata_definition_files/20250730_masterdata_of_controlled_vocabulary_dfg_device_code.xlsx). Please ensure that you follow the [rules and best practices for Masterdata definition](/en/masterdata_definition/best_practices) and check the Excel files with the [Masterdata checker](https://mdc.datastore.bam.de/) before you make them available to the Data Store team via GitHub repository or via email at datastore@bam.de. Information about how to create a new repository in the Github can be found [here](https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/start-your-journey/uploading-a-project-to-github#step-1-create-a-new-repository-for-your-project). You can also create your repository or fork it from [GitHub BAM research](https://github.com/BAMresearch). To Share your GitHub repository with the Data Store team, go to your repository in GitHub, copy the URL from the browser address bar and sent it via email to datastore@bam.de.', '## Masterdata The term "Masterdata" describes all information structures and plugins that are used to define metadata in openBIS (i.e., masterdata = "meta-metadata"). Masterdata is comprised of Entity types, i.e., [*Collection*](/en/concepts#collection), [*Object*](/en/concepts#object) and [*Dataset*](/en/concepts#dataset) types, as well as [*Property*](/en/concepts#property) types, [controlled vocabularies](/en/concepts#controlled-vocabulary) and related scripts (e.g., dynamic property plugins and entity validation scripts). Domain-specific masterdata have to be defined by the Data Store Stewards of the BAM divisions, but can only be imported to the openBIS instance (and edited) by Instance Admins.', "## Organising Masterdata Definition Files Each entity type (except *Property* types)/controlled vocabulary must be represented in a separate Excel file for easier organisation and findability. Please make sure that the Excel file also includes all (newly created) dependencies such as new controlled vocabularies, new Dynamic Property and Entity Validation Scripts. Ensure that the individual Excel files and the vocabulary code listed in the Excel file of the object type are consistent. If the Masterdata you generate uses existing vocabulary types (e.g., BAM_OE) or scripts (e.g. date_range_validation.py), they don't need to be sent."]
response:
The best practices for defining Masterdata in the BAM Data Store and openBIS focus on consistency, reusability, and clarity. Here‚Äôs a structured overview:  

1. **Keep Masterdata Generic and Specific as Needed**  
   Define Masterdata to be as generic as possible while meeting specific requirements. Avoid division-specific codes (e.g., `BAM_FBX.Y_ROOM_TEMPERATURE`) to ensure reusability across projects.  

2. **Reuse Existing Definitions**  
   Prioritize reusing established entity types (e.g., *Collection*, *Object*, *Dataset*) and controlled vocabularies from other groups. This reduces duplication and ensures alignment with broader standards.  

3. **Use Excel Templates for Organization**  
   Each entity type (except *Property* types) and controlled vocabulary should be defined in separate Excel files. Include all dependencies (e.g., new vocabularies, scripts) in these files for clarity and ease of review.  

4. **Validate with the Masterdata Checker**  
   Use the [Masterdata Checker tool](https://mdc.datastore.bam.de/) to verify your definitions before sharing them. This ensures compliance with rules and identifies potential issues.  

5. **Follow Naming and Structure Guidelines**  
   - Avoid division-specific prefixes in codes or labels.  
   - Ensure consistency between Excel files and referenced vocabularies (e.g., codes in object type files must match those in controlled vocabulary files).  

6. **Collaborate with Instance Admins**  
   While Data Store Stewards (DSSt) can draft Masterdata using templates, instance admins are required to register it in openBIS. Share your work via GitHub repositories or email (datastore@bam.de) for review.  

By adhering to these practices, you ensure Masterdata remains scalable, maintainable, and aligned with the BAM Data Store‚Äôs goals. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example of an Excel template or a step-by-step guide! üòä
reference: To ensure a consistent set of Masterdata in the BAM Data Store, we are introducing some rules, naming conventions, and recommendations when creating Spaces , Projects , entity types ( Collection , Object , Dataset , and Property types) and controlled vocabularies. > In general, Masterdata should be as generic as possible and as specific as necessary . It is encouraged to re-use existing entity types and vocabularies from other groups. For this reason, the use of division-specific information in the codes and labels of entity types (e.g., "BAM_FBX.Y_ROOM_TEMPERATURE") should be avoided. {.is-info}

user_input: Who is responsible for registering Masterdata and how can Data Store Stewards contribute?
retrieved_contexts: ['# The Process of Masterdata Definition Only instance admins can register [Masterdata](/en/concepts#masterdata) in openBIS. Since Data Store Stewards (DSSt) have group admin but not instance admin rights in the `main` Data Store instance, they cannot register domain/division-specific Masterdata on their own. They can use one of the Masterdata Excel templates. To create an Object Type e.g., [Instrument](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata#a-masterdata-excel-template-example) or a Controlled Vocabulary e.g., [DFG_DEVICE_CODE](/masterdata_definition_files/20250730_masterdata_of_controlled_vocabulary_dfg_device_code.xlsx). Please ensure that you follow the [rules and best practices for Masterdata definition](/en/masterdata_definition/best_practices) and check the Excel files with the [Masterdata checker](https://mdc.datastore.bam.de/) before you make them available to the Data Store team via GitHub repository or via email at datastore@bam.de. Information about how to create a new repository in the Github can be found [here](https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/start-your-journey/uploading-a-project-to-github#step-1-create-a-new-repository-for-your-project). You can also create your repository or fork it from [GitHub BAM research](https://github.com/BAMresearch). To Share your GitHub repository with the Data Store team, go to your repository in GitHub, copy the URL from the browser address bar and sent it via email to datastore@bam.de.', '# The Process of Masterdata Definition Only instance admins can register [Masterdata](/en/concepts#masterdata) in openBIS. Since Data Store Stewards (DSSt) have group admin but not instance admin rights in the `main` Data Store instance, they cannot register domain/division-specific Masterdata on their own. For this reason, we use the possibility to export Masterdata from one openBIS instance and import it in another one to offer the DSSt two options for defining Masterdata of the Division: 1. They can register Masterdata using the Admin UI of the `training` Data Store instance and [export it as Excel files](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata#exporting-masterdata-from-the-admin-ui). For directions on how to register entity types in the Admin UI, please check the [openBIS documentation](https://openbis.readthedocs.io/en/20.10.12-plus/). 2. They can skip the Admin UI and use one of the Masterdata Excel templates. To create an Object Type e.g., [Instrument](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata#a-masterdata-excel-template-example) or a Controlled Vocabulary e.g., [DFG_DEVICE_CODE](/masterdata_definition_files/20250730_masterdata_of_controlled_vocabulary_dfg_device_code.xlsx).', 'New Projects can be registered by Data Store Stewards (DSSt(s)) with Group Admin [roles](/en/concepts#roles-and-rights) in division‚Äôs **private** Inventory *Spaces*. Projects in **public** Inventory *Projects* need to be registered by the Data Store team (Instance Admins), please contact at datastore@bam.de.', 'Masterdata defintion in the BAM Data Store: - [The Process of Masterdata Definition](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata) - [Best Practices for Masterdata Definition](/en/masterdata_definition/best_practices) - [Masterdata checker](https://mdc.datastore.bam.de/) - [How to use Masterdata checker](/en/masterdata_definition/masterdata_checker) - [The Process of Masterdata Definition for phase 4](/en/masterdata_definition/definition_of_masterdata_for_phase4)', 'Question: Who is responsible for maintaining the Data Store? Answer: The Data Store is operated as a central service by the central IT (VP.2). Training and consulting is provided by the eScience section (VP.1). The divisions themselves are responsible for the content of their group and maintenance of metadata and data.']
response:
The responsibility for registering Masterdata in openBIS lies with **instance admins**, as they hold the necessary permissions to manage this process. However, **Data Store Stewards (DSSt)** play a crucial role in contributing to Masterdata definition through two key methods:  

1. **Using the Training Instance‚Äôs Admin UI**: DSSt can register Masterdata (e.g., Object Types or Controlled Vocabularies) in the `training` Data Store instance‚Äôs Admin UI. Once registered, they can **export the data as Excel files** for further use or collaboration.  
2. **Excel Templates**: DSSt can directly use pre-designed Masterdata Excel templates (e.g., for creating Instrument types or Controlled Vocabularies like DFG_DEVICE_CODE). These templates must be validated using the **Masterdata checker** tool before sharing via GitHub or email with the Data Store team.  

By following best practices and ensuring compliance with guidelines, DSSt enable the creation and maintenance of domain-specific Masterdata while working within their role constraints. Let me know if you‚Äôd like an example of an Excel template or steps for exporting data!

They can use one of the Masterdata Excel templates. To create an Object Type e.g., Instrument or a Controlled Vocabulary e.g., DFG_DEVICE_CODE.

response:
Data Store Stewards can define Masterdata using the export/import workflow by following these steps:  

1. **Register Masterdata in the Training Instance**: Use the Admin UI of the `training` Data Store instance to create Masterdata (e.g., Object Types or Controlled Vocabularies). This requires instance admin rights, which DSSt have access to.  

2. **Export to Excel**:  
   - Navigate to **Object Types** or **Vocabulary Types** in the Admin UI.  
   - Select the entity type(s) you want to export.  
   - Go to the **EXPORTS** tab and ensure "Import Compatible: Yes" is selected.  
   - If the entity type has new dependencies (e.g., controlled vocabularies or validation scripts not in the `main` instance), check "Include dependencies: Yes".  
   - Export the data as an Excel file, ensuring "Columns: All (default order)" is selected to preserve formatting for import.  

3. **Prepare for Import**:  
   - Rename the exported files according to the naming conventions.  
   - Reorganize files if needed, ensuring each entity type (except *Property* types) and controlled vocabulary are in separate files.  
   - Verify consistency between files and vocabulary codes.  

4. **Upload to GitHub**:  
   - Share the organized Excel files via a GitHub repository.  
   - Ensure files comply with [Masterdata best practices](/en/masterdata_definition/best_practices) and use the [Masterdata checker](https://mdc.datastore.bam.de/) to validate them before submission.  

5. **Import into Main Instance**:  
   - The Data Store team will import the files into the `main` instance, applying the defined Masterdata to the system.  

This workflow allows DSSt to define Masterdata without direct instance admin rights in the `main` instance, leveraging the export/import functionality to streamline collaboration.
